loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth A. sells building materials at Nyankumasi near Cape Coast. Elizabeth has received junior high education. She is married and has 5 dependents. Her husband is a farmer.

Elizabeth has been selling building materials since 1990. She is responsible for helping her husband pay rent, utility bills, and other basic expenses of the family. Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her to increase the sale of building materials to meet the increase in demand by her customers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest for the expansion of her sales of building materials.

loans.use: additional capital to  increase the sale of building materials

loans.name: Parvin

texts.en:
Parvin is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town, now settled in the Fuzuli region, in Mahmudlu village.

This young man was born in 1988 and is single. He has been in butchery business for 3 years. His net profit minimum is 200 AZN. Every week, Parvin buys 2-3 calves from the markets to cut up for sale. For example if he buys 1 calf = 500 AZN, he will cut up this calf and sell it for 700 AZN. Now he needs a loan of 950 AZN to buy 2 calves to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy 2 calves for meat for re-sale

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace A. sells fish which she buys from the fishermen, bringing them home for processing and preservation, and then sending them to the market for sale at Katakyiasi near Cape Coast. Grace has received junior high education. She is married and has 3 children. Her husband is a merchant.

Grace has been selling fish since 2006. She is responsible for helping pay the children's school fees and other family expenses. Her loan will be used to increase her capital to buy fish in larger quantities for processing and sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest back for the expansion of her business selling processed fish.

loans.use: to increase her capital to buy fish in larger quantities

loans.name: María Guadalupe

texts.es:
La señora María Guadalupe G. tiene más de 21 años con su negocio de venta de ropa usada y nueva, este es el ingreso de su familia. Ya que tiene a dos hijas bajo su responsabilidad y están estudiando la universidad, ella tiene poco que se quedo viuda y tiene que sacar adelante a sus hijas. 
 Esta solicitando un préstamo para surtir su negocio de más mercancía y de ropa nueva y de temporada de verano, y así tener más ingresos a su familia. Planea pagar este crédito con los ingresos de su negocio.
texts.en:
Maria Guadalupe Gonzalez has operated her business selling new and used clothing for more than 21 years. It's the source of income for her family. She has two daughters for whom she is responsible, both of whom are studying at the university, and she only has the little that was left to her when she was widowed. She's determine to see her daughters do better. She's applying for a loan to stock her business with more merchandise, new clothes and seasonal clothes for the summer so that she can increase the family's income. She plans to repay the loan from the income from the business.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise for resale.

loans.name: Fidencio

texts.es:
El señor Fidencio P. tiene poco tiempo que adquirió su vivienda por medio de un crédito gubernamental, pero le esta haciendo falta las protecciones de las puertas y ventanas. 
 Don Fidencio ya ha tenido tres créditos con FVP los cuales pago puntual mente. Está solicitando un préstamo para poder realizar esta mejora lo más pronto posible ya que él y su esposa trabajan todo el día, y en la casa solo esta una hija y quieren que este segura mientras ellos no se encuentren en la casa
texts.en:
Fidencio Perez recently bought his house with a government loan, but now he needs to protect it by adding security gates on the doors and windows. He has taken out three loans with FVP, all of which he's repaid on time. He's applying for a loan so that he can make this improvement as soon as possible. He and his wife work all day and a daughter is there alone. He wants to make sure she's safe when they're not at home.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Put secruity gates on doors and windows.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph O., 35 and married with three children, all students, lives with his family in a business center called Abofour, a busy market town in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. A trader since his boyhood, Joseph has been selling yams for over 15 years, acquiring them from the small towns nearby and then selling them at the local market. At times, he also sells beans, groundnuts or any other cereals, depending upon availability.

Joseph is requesting the loan in order to increase the quantity of foodstuffs that he buys on each trip so as to reduce his transportation costs and be able to supply to a sizeable market. This loan will enable him to save more to better support his wife in taking care of the family.

loans.use: To buy yams in bulk.

loans.name: Laura Segura

texts.es:
Laura Segura B. es una señora de 39 años vecina de una pequeña comunidad rural montañosa de Costa Rica llamada San Cristóbal Norte. En su comunidad se desarrollan actividades como la producción de café, hortalizas, así como el comercio y la producción de artesanías. Laura lleva 20 años casada y tiene tres hijos: Adriana de 19, Karen de 17 y Kevin de 14 años. Los tres son estudiantes. Cuando se casaron su esposo era un agricultor y ella se dedicaba a las labores del hogar. 
Con el deseo de mejorar su condición de vida buscaron alternativas diferentes y desde hace 15 años iniciaron juntos un negocio de confección de ropa. Al principio no conocían nada del negocio así que fueron experimentando poco a poco. Actualmente doña Laura elabora diferentes tipos de prendas de vestir que luego vende en negocios de la comunidad y sus alrededores con ayuda de su esposo. Su negocio ha hecho que la condición de vida de su familia haya mejorado mucho. La principal satisfacción para ella es haber logrado que todos sus hijos puedan estudiar.
Doña Laura forma parte de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal de San Cristóbal Norte (SACRIN), una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Como socia ha recibido un total de 10 micro-préstamos que le han permitido crecer como empresaria y atender las necesidades de su hogar. Todo esto le ha permitido mejorar su autoestima al pasar de ser una persona dedicada a las labores del hogar a ser una empresaria. 
Actualmente doña Laura requiere un préstamo de 1.200 dólares para comprar una máquina especial (marca Kober). Esta máquina le permitirá hacer ruedos en blusas, camisetas y otras prendas de vestir. Con esta inversión espera poder aumentar su producción y mejorar la calidad de los productos. Doña Laura dice que gracias a este préstamo podrá ofrecer mejores opciones para sus clientes.
texts.en:
Laura Segura B. is 39 years old and lives near a small, rural, mountain community in Costa Rica called San Cristóbal Norte. In her town the people work in such activities as coffee production, vegetable farming, commerce, and the production of crafts. Laura has been married for 20 years and has three children: Adriana, who is 19, Karen, who is 17, and Kevin, who is 14. All three are students. When they got married, her husband was a farmer and she worked in the home. They hoped to improve their living conditions, so they looked for alternatives. Fifteen years ago they started a business making clothes. At first they didn’t know anything about the business, so they experimented bit by bit. Now, Laura makes different types of clothing and sells it to businesses in the community and nearby towns, with the help of her husband. The business has greatly improved her family’s living conditions. Her greatest satisfaction is the fact that all of their children are able to study. Laura is part of the Empresa de Crédito Comunal de San Cristóbal Norte (SACRIN) (Communal Credit Enterprise of San Cristóbal Norte), one of the 100 EDESA partner organizations in Costa Rica. As a member, she has received a total of 10 micro loans, which have allowed her to grow as an entrepreneur and to provide for her household’s needs. All of this has allowed her to improve her self-esteem, as she has gone from being a homemaker to a business owner. Laura is currently requesting a loan of $1,200.00 to buy a special sewing machine (Kober brand). This sewing machine will allow her to make hems in blouses, t-shirts, and other clothing items. With this investment, she hopes to increase her production and improve the quality of her products. Laura says that thanks to this loan, she will be able to offer better options to her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a special sewing machine (Kober brand)

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Married with four children, three boys and a girl currently attending school, Theresa B. is a 44-year-old trader in cereals such as maize who believes that hard work and dedication are the primary antidotes to poverty.

She started this business 11 years ago from Koforidua, but relocated to Abofour for greater market opportunity. Theresa is now requesting a loan to buy larger supplies of maize directly from the farmers to reduce her reliance on middlemen and their often very high prices, an especially important goal given the inflation caused by the current food crisis.

This loan will enable Theresa to better support her husband in taking care of their home and better meet the needs of her customers.

loans.use: To buy a larger supply of maize.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia B., 22, married with two children, one in school and one an infant, lives in Abofour, a town in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. For the past four years she has operated an open-air business peddling jeans, blouses, skirts, women’s slippers and dressing bags. Excessive exposure to the sun has led to hospitalization, and her doctor has advised her to begin conducting the business from an indoor venue.

In order to ultimately rent a shop from which to retail her products, Cecilia is requesting a loan to increase both the quality and quantity of her inventory. She is grateful for any assistance Kiva lenders can provide.

loans.use: To purchase jeans, ladies wear and slippers.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes A. is 56 years old and married with six children, three of whom are in school while the other three are independent. She lives with her family at Abofour. 

Agnes works very hard to support her husband by taking care of their home. They all live in her husband's family house. Agnes' independent children did not have the privilege of attending school, and are determined to help the young ones. In Ghana, Agnes said, if you don’t go to school, you are seen as useless, something she refuses to be.

She sells home products such as cooking utensils, plastic bowls, buckets and plates. She makes her sales by ‘hawking’, that is, by selling door-to-door in her community. Agnes' focus has helped her to save enough to support her kids in school to give them brighter future and hope. 

Agnes is applying for a loan to increase her stock of plastic materials and kitchen sets. She believes with that she can save enough to rent a single room. She would be very grateful that support as this would enable her assist more in taking care of the household.

loans.use: To increase her stock kitchen wares

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice S. is a 50-year-old trader; she is married and the mother of six children who are currently in school. 

Beatrice trades at the Abofour community market and has been trading for the past eight years. She trades in large quantity of vegetables supplies like onions, tomatoes, peppers and more. Through this business she has supported two of her children to the senior high school level.

She is now applying for a loan to increase her inventory and to scale up the business. She hopes to increase her savings to support the children's education to give them a future, and to support her husband in providing for the household.

loans.use: Increase fruit and vegetable inventory

loans.name: Firi

texts.en:
Firi A. is 28 years old, married, and the mother of two kids who are currently in school. She lives at Abofour in the Ashanti region of Ghana together with her family. Firi, as she is called, loves her husband very much and is respected here. 

She trades in lace and clothing materials. Lace is very useful in room and office decorations. The clothing material can be sewn and worn for almost every occasion. She started this business three years ago. Through hard work and commitment, she has been able to save enough of her profits to help take care of the kids. 

For lack of adequate working capital, Firi buys only a small amount of lace and clothing materials at a time, which she then sells by hawking (selling door-to-door). With this loan, Firi wants to purchase the lace and textiles in bulk to stock up her inventory. She will use part of her profits to provide her children with quality education.

loans.use: To purchase bulk textiles.

loans.name: Akosua

texts.en:
Akosua D. is 35 years old. She is married and the mother of four children. All her children are in school and are doing very well there. She has been trading in the community of Abofour where she lives with her family.

Akosua has been manufacturing palm oil for four years. Palm oil is produced from palm nut fruits; she then supplies the palm oil to food vendors for use in preparing their meals. She also travels to the villages to purchase additional palm oil when the demand becomes very high.

Akosua will use this loan to buy more palm nut fruits, as well as an electric milling machine to increase her efficiency and allow her to produce larger quantities. This will allow her to expand her business and earn more income to support her family and finance her children's education.

loans.use: To buy ingredients and an electric mill

loans.name: Gabriel

texts.en:
Gabriel A. is a 40-year-old married father of four children, all of whom are enrolled in a community school. Gabriel and his family live in a farming community called Abofour, a suburb of Offinso in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Abofour is a forest reserve area where most popular occupation is farming. There is a very high rate of illiteracy among adults in this community, and most families are only able to provide their children with a junior high school level education; this minimal education contributes to the high unemployment rate in Ghana, which is becoming a challenge for the government.

Gabriel is a seasoned farmer, having been farming cocoa and cereals such as maize for over five years. Through this he has managed to build a two-bedroom house in the village. In addition to operating his farm, Gabriel sells grocery products in a kiosk in the community in order to generate additional income to support his business.

However, he has been having difficulties with his farm because there is a disease attacking his cocoa crops. Therefore he is applying for loan assistance to buy implements such as fertilizers, agro-chemicals and spraying machines. This will allow him to harvest more this year and in the years ahead, thereby increasing his profits so he can better support his family and his children's education.

loans.use: To buy farming equipment and chemicals

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah T. is 38 years old and married. She has five children, who are currently in school. She lives with her family in Abofour, a busy market town in the Ashanti region of Ghana.

Hannah has been selling yams for over 10 years. She buys her goods from small towns nearby and sells them at the local market. She sometimes also buys and sells beans, groundnut or other cereals depending on availability. 

She is applying for a loan so she can increase the quantity of inventory she buys on each trip, so as to reduce her frequent travels while still being able to supply a sizable market. This would help her increase her income, allowing her to support her husband in providing for their family.

loans.use: To buy yam in bulk.

loans.name: Akua

texts.en:
Akua A., 40, is married and a mother of four. Two of her children are in senior high school, while two are in primary school. It has been Akua's dream to give her children a better education. 

Akua has been a food vendor for 15 years in the community market of Abofour, where she lives with her family. She sells rice with stew; her major customers are trader's. Her food is moderate and tastes good, attracting customers to her table.

Akua is applying for a loan to buy more bags of raw materials, such as rice, meat and charcoal. Increasing her stock would provide her with the resources to continue to provide cooked food and friend pastries even in as food prices continue to rise. She will use the proceeds from her work to support her children's education.

loans.use: To buy ingredients and raw materials

loans.name: Akosua

texts.en:
Akosua S., 50, is married with four children -- two boys and two girls. Her children have finished the village elementary school, but have not attended any schooling after that, instead just roaming the village. Akosua is concerned that her husband is not taking enough responsibility in caring for their children. The family lives in her husband's family house in Abofour, a farming community in Offinso in the Ashanti region of Ghana.

Akosua is a dynamic innovator and self-starter when it comes to her work. She sells bush meat in her community. Her suppliers provide her with bush meats such as grass cutter, antelope, deer and more, all of which have a big market share in Ghana. People from the big cities place orders with Akosua, which they then come pick up when the order is ready.

Demand for her products has been high, so Akosua is applying for a loan to purchase more bush meats and increase her inventory. It is her dream to be able to provide enough support and financial assistance for her children to return to school.

loans.use: To buy fresh bush meats and firewood.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary N., 40, is married and mother of five children; four of the children are attending government-sponsored primary school while the youngest is still breastfeeding. Mary and her family live in Abofour, in a rented apartment in the community. 

Mary prepares and sells kenkey in her neighborhood. Kenkey is prepared from milled maize grains, which are cooked and eaten with hot pepper and fried fish. Many Ghanaians enjoy kenkey as breakfast, lunch or dinner, and so Mary has many customers.

In addition to kenkey, Mary also sells raw foods, such as bags of maize, at the market square of Abofour. She has been trading for the past 10 years in order to help care for the family; it is her dream to increase her stock of raw materials to strengthen her business. She is now applying for a loan to do just this, by purchasing more raw materials including maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood. 

Mary hopes to increase her income to support her children, especially in their schooling. Mary had no opportunity for school, and wants her children to get an education.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of raw foods

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
Sophia N., 72, is married and living with her daughter to care for her seven grandchildren.

Sophia started trading foodstuffs 35 years ago; she is very serious about her business and believes hard work and dedication to be the antidotes to poverty. She also loves her work, saying she has selling in her blood and can't do anything else. 

Sophia trades in maize, beans, peanuts and more in the market of Abofour, the town where she lives. Sophia started this business with her mother while just a young lady, and has since inherited the business. At the time she began, she says, she did not realize the importance of an education as she does now. She continues to provide valuable resources for her family, and is doing all she can to support her grandchildren in their education.

Sophia is applying for a loan to buy a larger supply of inventory to serve her customers throughout the season, especially in the face of increasing prices due to the current food crisis in Ghana. This would allow her to continue to help support her family.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort K. is 37 years old and married. She has four children, all of whom are currently in school. She lives with her family in Abofour, a busy market town in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. 

Comfort has been operating her trading business for over 12 years; she primarily sells yams, but also sells beans, groundnut or other foods. She buys her goods from small towns nearby, sometimes traveling as far as Goaso in the Brong Ahafo region when yams are scarce. She then sells her goods at the local market, mostly to travelers. She has been successful enough to rent out a store in the market center from which she sells her products.

Comfort hopes to increase the quantity of food stuffs that she buys on each trip, so as to cut down on her frequent travels and still be able to supply to a sizable market. This would enable her to save more and support her husband in providing for their family, and especially for the children's education.

loans.use: To buy yam in bulk to re-sell

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace A. is 51 years old, married, and the mother of eight children. Six of the children finished junior level while two are still in school through the help of the government's free, compulsory education. Grace lives with her family in Abofour, in the Ashanti region of Ghana.

Grace has been a food vendor for eight years. She prepares and sells fried yams and cooked beans with fried ripe plantains by the roadside of Abofour. Grace cuts the yams and plantains into slices, fries them, and arranges them in a glass box to attract customers. She also sells beans and gari, a delicacy meal many Ghanaian enjoy daily for either breakfast or lunch.

Her business is doing well and she wants to expand her operations to serve more customers. She is applying for a loan to buy more ingredients, including grains, vegetables, rice, yams and assorted meats. She hopes to increase her income and savings to improve her family's well-being, as she would be able to support her husband in paying for the children's educational needs.

Grace belongs to the community group called ‘Nyame Nhyira’, which means "God Blessing Trust Group". In this group, members guarantee one another to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy ingredients

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa F. is 40 years old. She is married with three children. Currently her eldest child who is a girl is an apprentice hairdresser, and the two others are in school. She lives with her husband at Abofour in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Abofour happens to be a farming community and the two of them are in crops and cocoa farming.

Adwoa owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items like rice, evaporated milk, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oil, washing powder, toilet soaps, candies, biscuits, etc. in the local market. Adwoa means Monday-born; she has been in this business for the past 25 years. She wants to use the loan to buy bulk supplies of rice, canned foods and drinks, milk, assorted food spices, washing soaps and powders, etc. to expand her business. She said no family member is able to assist her with financial support because they are also in hardship like her. She wants a loan to expand her business. Adwoa hopes to make good income from the expanded business to enable her to provide the children with quality education.

Adwoa belongs to a village bank called ‘Nyame Asem’ which means the WORD OF GOD. She also hopes to receive GHS 800 to make business progress by restocking her shop. This would enable her to save more to help her husband take care of the children's educational needs. Fortunately she has also registered with the Ghana national health insurance which takes care of her medical bills free of charge, depending on the condition. We encourage our clients to do so, so that when you lend to her she would not spend her working capital (loan assistance) on medical expenses.

loans.use: To buy bulk supplies of rice, canned foods and drinks, etc.

loans.name: Akua

texts.en:
Akua P. is 70 years old, married, and a mother of ten children. She lives with her family in Abofour in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Currently, all of Akua's children are grown-ups and are fully independent. She lives in a typical farming community and is a multi-business woman. Aside from other things, she sells cooking utensils, plastic bowls, spoons, etc. Akua is also a seasoned farmer who farms cocoa and maize. 

Akua started farming when she was a kid and has grown with it even now. Realizing the opportunity in other areas, she decided to add cooking utensil sales to her farming, and this was started about four years ago. She wants the loan to go toward purchasing more assorted cooking utensils. With the loan, Akua believes she can make lots of profit to buy agro-chemicals, fertilizers, and other farm inputs to sustain the growth of the farm. 

Akua belongs to a village bank called 'Daniel.' She also hope to receive GH¢500 to make business progress by restocking her inventory. This would enable her save more to support her husband in taking care of the home.

loans.use: To purchase cooking utensils to sell and fertilizer for the farm

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia A. is 50 years old, divorced, and a mother of four children. Two of her children are in school through the help of government free compulsory education. She lives with her children in their family house in Abofour, a suburb of Offinso in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Felicia works tirelessly to provide for the needs of her children as a single mother. Her husband abandoned his responsibility, leaving everything on her. The family responsibilities rest on her indeed; she provides food on the table, pays the utility bills, etc.

Felicia was in tears and at the verge of giving up when we spoke to her concerning her current situation. She is an artisan and manufacturer of mortar. One may wonder what we use it for in Ghana. It serves only one purpose here.

Mortar is used to pound fufu; it serves as the bowl in which the cassava and plantain are poured in to be pound with a pistol. There is a particular tree in the forest that can be used to design or manufacture the mortar. Felicia goes to the forest and places the timber logs in order to be used for the mortar. It is said that the Ashanties use mortar more than the other tribes in Ghana. 

For the past two years now, Felicia has been doing this to take care of her home. It has become a challenge as she finds it difficult to get wood for the mortar as a result of a government warning on the frequent cutting of timber in our forest reserves. She is requesting the loan to buy wood to manufacture the mortar. With her larger customer base, Felicia believes she can make lots of profit from the business growth to help her kids in school. Felicia belongs to a village bank called ‘Onuado’ which means brotherly love. She also hopes to receive GH¢1000 to make business progress by restocking her inventory. This would enable her save more to support her family.

loans.use: To buy timber logs needed to make mortar

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en:
Emelia A. is 45 years old. She is divorced and a mother with four children. Two of her children are in school and two are learning trades in the city of Kumasi. She and her children hail from Abofour and she operates her shop in town. She was divorced 10 years ago and has since not seen the children's father. She is a very hardworking and supportive woman and the responsibility of the family rests on her shoulders.

She owns and operates a beauty and Raster hairdo saloon in her neighborhood. Emelia is a very skillful and talented hair dresser, who adds a lot of beauty to the hair of her many customers. Emelia uses weavons and meshes to plait  her client’s hair to add beauty. She has been doing this for the past five years to make a living. She said though it generates income it is not enough to take care of the home. She believes in efficiency and effectiveness of service, therefore she wants to use the loan to buy larger quantities of hair products like weavons, mesh, threads etc. to avoid shortages and increase her business. 

Emelia belongs to a village bank called ‘Onuado’ which means Brotherly love. She also hopes to receive a loan of GH¢1000 to increase her business and restock her inventory. This would enable her to save more to support children's education. She has been encouraged to register for health insurance to take care of the medical expenses of her family.

loans.use: To buy larger quantities of hair products like weavons, thread, needle and etc.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth A. is thirty nine years old. She is widowed and a single mother with one child who is currently in school with the help of government free and compulsory education for every child. She lives at Abofour, a farming community in the Ashanti region of Ghana. 

They say death is inevitable but Elizabeth never expected her husband would leave her so suddenly. He died out of a minor ache and he passed away when he was rushed to the hospital. Because of this, she is struggling hard to provide support for her family.
  
She sells cereals like bags of rice and wheat in the community market and she is trying to build her name in the market. However, she is still constrained with inadequate funds to make her business progress. She deems this an opportunity to expand her business and wants to use this loan to buy more bags of rice, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of body and hair creams etc.and increase her stock of goods available for sale. She has run this business for 10 years and she has used the proceeds for her household need. She travels to Kumasi which is one the busiest market to buy  her supply of goods. 

Elizabeth belongs to a village bank called Born Again. She also hopes to receive GH¢600 to build her business by restocking her inventory. This would enable her save more to support her childs education. She has been encouraged to register with the health insurance to take care of the medical expenses of her family.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice and wheat.

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en:
Georgina A. is a 47-year-old local restaurant operator. She is widowed and has four kids and all have completed the junior high school. Georgina currently lives at Abofour with her kids. It was her husband’s dream to provide quality education for his children before he passed away.

Georgina has been in food provision for eight years now. She understands customer ethics and is also aware that the customer is cash for that reason she does not down-play quality and excellent service. She prepares and sells local foods like fufu, banku and other local dishes. Fufu is prepared from pounded cassava and plantains, taken with all kinds of soup. Banku is prepared from milled maize grains and it is taken with hot pepper or soup. With her tasty meals she has attracted lots of customers in the area where she works. Therefore it has become necessary to employ additional hands to assist her in her food delivering service.

Georgina says prices of raw materials have gone up significantly and she needs the support of a loan to enable her to meet her production expenditure. With the loan, she wants to purchase more raw materials like bags of maize, baskets of cassava, plantains, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood to prepare her meals. She would be grateful for your assistance. She believes she can fulfill her late husband's dream by providing the children with education. Georgina belongs to a village bank called Sarah. She hopes to receive GHS 400 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy raw materials like maize, cassava, plantains, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood.

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita N. is thirty-eight years old. She is married and the mother of six children. Currently two of them are in school; the rest have finished junior high school and are about to continue. Rita lives with her husband and children at Abofour in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Her husband happens to be a professional carpenter who manufactures furniture.

Rita has been a food vendor for eight years now in Abofour community school where she lives with her family. She sells ‘ampesi’ and rice with stew; this food is mostly purchased by the school children during their breaks. Ampesi is cooked and enjoyed with any kind of stew. Rita says the demand for her food has being extended to the people in the community so when she closes in the morning, she prepares some in the afternoon and sells it in the community market.

Rita wants the loan to buy more bags of raw materials like rice, meat, charcoal, etc. She is convinced that the loan would help her increase her stock in the event of a price hike and she would be more capable of preparing food. Rita wants to use the proceeds to support her kids in their education. She says she would be grateful for your assistance. It has also been her dream to add to her existing business the sale of fruit such as bananas so that she can make additional income to help her husband take care of the kids. Rita belongs to a village bank called ‘Bisa Nyame’ which means "Ask GOD". She hopes to receive GHS 1000 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs such as yams, plantains, bags of rice, meat, fish, spices and charcoal, etc.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa I. is a 25-year-old. She is single and a mother with one child who is currently in primary school. She is very hard-working and resourceful for her family. She sells bags of maize, and she also sells food in her neighborhood. She has been selling "kenkey" for the past six years now. Hawa prepares kenkey from milled maize. It is well packed in maize leaves and it is left to boil for 2 hours to be served with hot pepper or any gravy stew together with fried fish.

Hawa obtains her supply of foodstuffs like maize, vegetables, and charcoal from the surrounding villages near Abofour. Hawa then retails them to her customers. She wants to use the loan to buy bulk supplies of charcoal, maize, fish and vegetables to increase her inventory, especially in this season of "hamatan" where demand for her goods is high. She hopes the loan will enable her to increase her savings to pay her child's educational fees and also to save part to restock her inventory. Hawa belongs to a village bank called ‘Naomi’. She hopes to receive a loan in the amount of GHS 700 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy bulk supplies of charcoal, maize, fish etc.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys N. started her business three years ago in the village where she lives with her family. Gladys is a food vendor and she prepares and serves what we call ‘obrayo’ (porridge) and "baflot" in a community school. Obrayo is prepared from dried maize; this maize is soaked in water for about three days before it is ground, but not too fine. This food (porridge) is just like any other porridge but with this one you feel the maize whilst enjoying it. Obrayo can be taking with bread or "baflot". It can be taken either as breakfast or lunch and it is purely carbohydrate food.

Gladys is married with three kids who are currently in school. Through her excellent food standards and moderate prices she has attracted many customers. She is requesting a loan to buy more bags of maize, sugar, milk, flour, margarine, charcoal, etc. so that she can remain in business. Gladys belongs to a village bank called ‘Naomi’. She hopes to receive GHS 700 to make business progress. And she would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: For the purchase of maize, flour, margarine, milk etc.

loans.name: Danny Villalobos

texts.es:
Danny Villalobos R. es un señor de 31 años de edad. Vive en una casa propia con su esposa. Aún no tiene hijos. Su familia se ha dedicado desde hace muchos años a la ganadería tanto para leche como para carne. Él siguió los mismos pasos y actualmente tiene una finca que es la que le ayuda a salir adelante. 
La comunidad en la cual vive Danny se llama El Sauce de Santa Teresita de Turrialba. Es una pequeña comunidad rural de unos dos mil habitantes. Sus pobladores se dedican a la producción de leche y siembra de café. Tiene un relieve irregular y mucho del terreno se mantiene como bosque tropical húmedo. La comunidad tiene paisajes muy pintorescos que combinan el bosque tropical con dos lindas lagunas, plantaciones de café y lecherías. El Sauce se localiza aproximadamente a hora y media en bus de Turrialba, el centro de comercio más cercano, sin embargo varias veces al año, el camino se vuelve intransitable por las lluvias que caen en la zona. Este es sin duda uno de los principales desafíos para la comunidad. Cuando no existían actividades muchas personas optaron por salir a buscar trabajos en Turrialba o en fincas bananeras ubicadas en el Atlántico de Costa Rica. Actualmente los precios del café y la leche han mejorado por lo tanto los vecinos buscan cómo invertir en proyectos en la misma zona.
Hace dos años, se instaló en la comunidad una planta de elaboración de quesos de la Asociación de Productores de Leche de El Sauce. Por lo tanto, en los últimos dos años Danny ha ido especializándose en la producción de leche que luego vende a esta planta. 
El queso de la región donde vive Danny es famoso en todo Costa Rica. Es un queso fresco que se le conoce tradicionalmente como “Queso Turrialba”. A los “ticos” (como se les conoce a los habitantes de Costa Rica) les gusta mucho comprar el queso Turrialba para comerlo en el desayuno junto con tortillas, arroz, frijoles y huevos. Por esta razón, el mercado para el queso que se hará con la leche que venda Danny es muy bueno.
Danny desea obtener un microcrédito para comprar una vaca lechera más y así aumentar la producción de leche. El sabe que contar con una vaca más es un mayor sacrificio y demandará más trabajo pero dice que si quiere sacar su familia adelante tiene que esforzarse en producir más. Danny dice que sacará este préstamo para mejorar la calidad de vida de su esposa y de él en este momento y si con el paso de los años hay hijos que tengan una mejor calidad de vida y tal vez que ellos puedan tener la oportunidad de estudiar que él no tuvo.
Actualmente Danny ordeña a mano en una pequeña instalación de madera que acondicionó como sala de ordeño. Si aumenta la producción espera ir haciendo un local mejor y en unos años poder comprar un equipo de ordeño. También le gustaría ir mejorando los pastos con variedades más adecuadas para la producción de leche y así contar con una finca que le permita producir más.
Danny es cliente de la Asociación de Productores de El Sauce, una organización local socia de la microfinanciera EDESA. Gracias a su vinculación con esta organización ha obtenido ya 5 microcréditos y los ha cancelado satisfactoriamente. Los montos han ido incrementando desde los US$ 300, US$ 430, US$ 500, US$ 600 y US$ 700. Actualmente  Danny necesita un préstamo por $1.000 para comprar su vaca lechera.
texts.en:
Danny Villalobos R. is 31 years old. He lives in his own house with his wife. They do not have children yet. His family has had cattle for many years, for both milk production and meat production. He has followed the same path and now has a farm that helps him to get ahead. The community where Danny lives is called El Sauce de Santa Teresita de Turrialba. It is a small, rural town of two thousand inhabitants. The people of the town work in milk production and coffee farming. The topography is hilly and most of the area is maintained as tropical rainforest. The town has very picturesque landscapes that combine the tropical forest with pretty ponds, coffee plantations, and dairies. El Sauce is located approximately one and a half hours by bus from Turrialba, the closest center of commerce. Even so, several times a year the road becomes impassible because of the rains. This is, without a doubt, one of the biggest challenges for the community. When there weren’t many jobs, many people chose to leave to look for work in Turrialba or in banana plantations located on the Atlantic coast of Costa Rica. Lately the prices of coffee and milk have improved, so now people from the area are looking for ways to invest in projects there. Two years ago a cheese processing plant was started by the Milk Producers Association of El Sauce. Because of this, for the past two years Danny has been specializing in producing milk that he then sells to the cheese factory. The cheese from the region where Danny lives is famous throughout Costa Rica. It is a fresh cheese that is traditionally known as “Turriabla Cheese.” Ticos (a nick-name for the people Costa Rica) like to buy Turrialba cheese to eat it at breakfast, along with tortillas, rice, beans, and eggs. This is why the market for the milk that Danny sells, which is then made into cheese, is very good. Danny hopes to obtain a micro-loan to buy another dairy cow so that he can increase the milk production. He knows that having another cow is a big sacrifice and will require more work, but he says that if he wants to help his family get ahead, he’ll have to work hard to produce more. Danny says he will take out this loan to improve the quality of life for his wife and himself right now; if the years pass and there are children, he hopes they will have a better quality of life and maybe they can have the opportunity to study that he didn’t have. Currently, Danny milks by hand in a small wooden shed that he set up as a milking room. If his production increases, he hopes to construct a better building and then, in a few years, be able to buy a milking machine. He would also like to improve his pasture with varieties of grass that are better suited to milk production and in this way have a farm that will allow him to produce more. Danny is a client of the Producers Association of El Sauce, a local partner organization of the microfinance organization EDESA. Because of his ties to this organization, he has received 5 micro-loans and he has repaid them satisfactorily. The amounts have increased from US$300.00, to US$430.00, to US$500.00, to US$600.00, and to $700.00. Danny now needs a loan of $1,000.00 to buy his dairy cow.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Deyanira Montero

texts.es:
Deyanira Montero J. es una madre soltera con 45 años de edad. Sólo tuvo un hijo que ya es mayor de edad y se atiende sólo. Ella vive en una pequeña casa donde también instaló su negocio, una pulpería (tiendita de abarrotes) para vender productos básicos a sus vecinos. 
La comunidad en la cual ella vive se llama El Sauce de Santa Teresita de Turrialba. Es una pequeña comunidad rural de unos dos mil habitantes. Sus pobladores se dedican a la producción de leche y siembra de café. Tiene un relieve irregular y mucho del terreno se mantiene como bosque tropical húmedo. La comunidad tiene paisajes muy pintorescos que combinan el bosque tropical con dos lindas lagunas, plantaciones de café y lecherías. El Sauce se localiza aproximadamente a hora y media en bus de Turrialba, el centro de comercio más cercano, sin embargo varias veces al año, el camino se vuelve intransitable por las lluvias que caen en la zona. Este es sin duda uno de los principales desafíos para la comunidad. Cuando no existían actividades muchas personas optaron por salir a buscar trabajos en Turrialba o en fincas bananeras ubicadas en el Atlántico de Costa Rica. Actualmente los precios del café y la leche han mejorado por lo tanto la población busca invertir con proyectos en la misma zona.
Doña Deyanira inició su negocio hace aproximadamente un año. Su objetivo es tener una actividad económica rentable que no la obligue emigrar a Turrialba a buscar trabajo como empleada doméstica. Aún no puede mantener abierto el negocio todo el tiempo que quisiera ya que no tiene suficiente capital como para invertirlo en comprar toda la mercadería necesaria. Ella comenta que al tener el negocio en su propia casa no tiene que pagar alquiler o construir un local lo cual le ayuda a que el negocio salga adelante.
Con el microcrédito que ha solicitado, ella desea comprar más mercadería que pueda vender para así hacer más grande el negocio y brindar un mejor servicio a sus vecinos. Específicamente comprará abarrotes básicos como arroz, frijoles, verduras, productos enlatados, refrescos, jabón, y todo lo que se refiere a la canasta básica del costarricense que vive en las zonas rurales. Deyanira comenta que el servicio que ella brinda es muy importante ya que no existe otra pulpería en la zona. Ella espera que el microcrédito le ayude a impulsar su negocio, colaborar con la comunidad y que las personas no tengan que viajar hasta Turrialba para comprar sus abarrotes.
Deyanira es cliente de la Asociación de Productores de El Sauce, una organización local socia de la microfinanciera EDESA. Gracias a su vinculación con esta organización, ella ha obtenido varios micropréstamos para su negocio los cuales ha pagado satisfactoriamente. Los montos han ido incrementando desde los US$ 200, US$ 550 y US$ 600. Actualmente ella necesita un préstamo por $1.000 para realizar la compra de la mercadería necesaria para ampliar su negocio.
texts.en:
Deyanira Montero J. is single mother who is 45 years old. She only had one son, and he is grown up and provides for himself. She lives in a small house where she also has her business, a small grocery store, where she sells basic products to her neighbors. The community in which she lives is called El Sauce de Santa Teresita de Turrialba. It is a small, rural town with two thousand inhabitants. They work primarily in milk production and coffee farming. It has a hilly topography and most of the area is maintained as tropical rainforest. The town has very picturesque landscapes that combine the tropical forest with pretty ponds, coffee plantations, and dairies. El Sauce is located approximately one-and-a-half hours by bus from Turrialba, the nearest center of commerce. However, several times per year the road becomes impassible due to the rains. This is, without a doubt, one of the greatest challenges for the community. When there weren’t many jobs, many people chose to leave to look for work in Turrialba or in banana plantations located on the Atlantic coast of Costa Rica. Lately the prices of coffee and milk have improved, so now people from the area are looking for ways to invest in projects there. Deyanira began her business approximately one year ago. Her goal is to have economically feasible work so that she won’t have to emigrate to Turrialba to work as domestic help. She still can’t keep her business open as much as she would like because she doesn’t have enough capital to invest in all of the necessary merchandise. She explains that having the business in her home means she doesn’t have to pay rent or construct a building, which helps her move ahead with her business. With the micro-loan she has requested, she hopes to buy more merchandise to sell and thereby grow the business and provide better service to her neighbors. Specifically, she will buy basic grocery goods, such as rice, beans, vegetables, canned goods, soft drinks, soap, and everything else that rural Costa Ricans typically need. Deyanira has commented that the service that she provides is very important because there is no other small grocery store in the area. She hopes the micro-loan will give momentum to her business and help her to collaborate with the community so that people won’t have to travel to Turrialbla to buy groceries. Deyanira is a client of the Producers Assocation of El Sauce, a local partner organization of the microfinance organization EDESA. Because of her ties to this organization, she has obtained several micro-loans for her business, which she has repaid satisfactorily. The amounts have increased from US$200.00, to US$550.00, to US$600.00. She currently needs a loan of $1,000.00 to buy the merchandise that is necessary to grow her business.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Ana

texts.es: Natural de Pusi (Distrito de Huancane), Ana de 31 años ha pasado gran parte de su vida, queriendo salir adelante, es soltera y vive en una casa alquilada y lo que más quiere es que su negocio progrese y así de esta manera mejorar su futuro. Cuando Ana llegó a Juliaca, solo tenia 14 años, pero traía consigo muchos deseos de superarse, así fue que años después, logró poner un negocio de venta de comida y ya son 9 años que lleva en este negocio, atendiendo con las mismas ganas de siempre, es una cocinera con una sazón muy exquisita, lo que hace que su pequeña carretilla de comida, sea la más visitada del mercado. Ella se divierte mucho cocinando para la gente, puesto que le encanta cocinar, anhela que su negocio prospere y poner un restaurante donde pueda atender mucho mejor a sus clientes y es que los días lluviosos le traen a Ana, muchas dificultades en sus ventas y no la dejan progresar como ella quisiera. Es el primer préstamo que Ana adquiere en Microfinanzas PRISMA y quiere cumplir con todas sus cuotas, porque sabe que ha adquirido una responsabilidad con su banco comunal y con ella misma. Ana quiere aumentar su capital y así poder comprar más víveres, para cocinar para más gente, además necesita arreglar su triciclo, ya que el paso de los años ha desgastado su funcionamiento.
texts.en:
Born in Pusi (District of Huancane), 31-year-old Ana, has spent most of her life trying to make ends meet. She is single. She lives at a rented house and her biggest dream is to see her business grow, to have a better future. When Ana arrived to Juliaca, she was only 14 years old, but she was committed to succeed. That is how years later she managed to open a food shop, which she’s been running for 9 years. She is an exquisite cook, which makes her small food wheelbarrow the most popular of the market. She has a great time cooking for other people. As she loves what she does, she also hopes her business would improve and even to have a restaurant in the future where she can still serve her customers during rainy days when it’s very difficult to make sales. This is the first loan she is requesting from Microfinanzas PRISMA and she is very confident she will make all payments in time, as she knows this is an important responsibility for her. Ana would like to increase her capital to purchase more provisions to be able to cook for more people. She also needs to fix her tricycle due to wear and tear.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Lopez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase provisions to prepare food for her customers

loans.name: Carlos

texts.es: A sus cortos 19 años, Carlos se ha dada cuenta, que para forjarse un futuro mejor, tiene que trabajar arduamente, vive alquilado en un cuarto de manera independiente, puesto que ya no quiere ser una carga más para sus padres. Son ya 2 años vendiendo celulares, los que lleva Carlos. Esta actividad le a traído muchas satisfacciones, sobre todo el poder mantenerse por sí mismo, él disfruta de informar a sus clientes sobre los beneficios de los nuevos equipos celulares que adquiere, puesto que siempre está informándose sobre los nuevos modelos y su funcionamiento, Carlos tiene ya muchos contactos y por eso es siempre el vendedor que tiene los modelos de celulares más buscados del mercado. Carlos trabaja solo y lo que menos le gusta de su trabajo, es decirle a sus clientes que ya no tiene el equipo celular que están buscando. En un futuro próximo, desea incrementar la cantidad de equipos celulares que compra, para siempre tener su negocio lleno y poder tener un mejor ingreso económico. Carlos se encuentra en su primer préstamo y espera ser muy puntual en sus cuotas, ya que al ser uno de los pocos varones en su banco comunal trata continuamente de ser responsable y respetuoso. Con el préstamo que solicita comprará nuevos y adecuados muebles (escritorios, asientos, etc), para atender mejor a sus clientes, muebles que tendrán un costo aproximado de 1000 nuevos soles, motivo por el cual Carlos aportará 300 nuevos soles de sus ahorros personales.
texts.en:
Young 19-year-old Carlos knows that in order to have a better future, he needs to work hard. He lives at a rented room alone, as he doesn’t want to be burden for his parents any longer. He’s been selling cell phones for 2 years. This activity had brought him many satisfactions, especially because it let him support himself. She enjoys helping his customers about new models and features. Carlos has many contacts, so he always offers the hottest cell phone models. He works alone, and the thing he enjoys the least about his work is to tell his customers he’s no longer selling the model they are looking for. In the near future, he would like to increase the amount of handsets he is buying right now, to have a full stock which will help him make a better income. This is Carlos’s first loan, and he hopes he would be able to make all payments in time. As he is one of the few male members of the bank, he is continually trying to be responsible and respectful. He will use this loan to purchase new and better furniture (desks, seats, etc), to provide his customers with a better service. Its approximate cost will be of 1000 new soles. He will also use 300 new soles out of his personal savings to pay for them.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Lopez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase new cell phones

loans.name: Silvia Castro

texts.es:
Silvia Castro A. es una joven señora de 26 años de edad que vive en las llanuras de la zona norte de Costa Rica, en una pequeña comunidad llamada San Rafael de Florencia de San Carlos. San Rafael es una comunidad rural en la cual la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la cría de ganado tanto para carne como para leche. Es una zona de clima caliente, la cual también es muy visitada por turistas que viajan a ver lugares el volcán Arenal, ríos con agua celeste, aguas termales, lagunas, montañas y otras bellezas naturales que se mantienen en la zona. Cerca de la zona también se produce agricultura, principalmente el cultivo de piña, yuca, naranjas y frijoles.
Silvia está casada con Carlos García y tienen una pequeña hija de dos meses de nacida que se llama Jimena. Silvia y Carlos trabajan juntos en una finca de 12 hectáreas que alquilan y en la cual también tienen una casa donde viven. En esta finca crían ganado desde hace dos años. Su familia tiene una amplia tradición ganadera ya que tanto su papá como su abuelo se dedicaban a esto. Silvia también está luchando para terminar sus estudios en la universidad, la cual va pagando con los ingresos que recibe por las actividades en la finca.
Con el deseo de tener más ingresos para mejorar su calidad de vida y poder seguir estudiando, Silvia requiere un micro crédito que le permita comprar tres terneros así como medicinas y vacunas para su desarrollo. Con el préstamo de US$ 1.000 espera invertir US $800 para comprar tres terneros y US $200 para comprar vitaminas, desparasitantes, vacunas, sal, minerales y melaza. El ganado lo espera vender en una de las tantas subastas cercanas a su comunidad. 
Silvia forma parte de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal de Florencia, una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Como socia este será el primer préstamo que reciba, pero ya ha realizado inversiones de capital como socia. Con este préstamo ella espera mejorar su negocio y de esta forma la lograr una mejor calidad de vida para su familia.
texts.en:
Silvia Castro A. is a young woman of 26 who lives in the small community of San Rafael de Florencia de San Carlos, in the North of Costa Rica. San Rafael is a rural community where most people raise livestock for milk and meat. It has a warm climate and is very popular with tourists who come to see the Arenal volcano, the clear blue rivers, hot springs, lakes, mountains and the natural beauty of the region. Pineapple, cassava, oranges and beans are some of the crops grown in the surrounding agricultural areas. Silvia is married to Carlos García and they have a two-month-old daughter named Jimena. Silvia and Carlos work together on a 12-hectare farm which they rent; this is also where their home is. They have been raising livestock on this farm for two years. Her family has a long tradition of raising livestock as both her father and grandfather were in the livestock business. Silvia is also working hard to finish her university degree which she pays for with the revenues from farming. Because she wants to increase her income to improve her quality of life and be able to continue studying, Silvia needs a microloan of USD $1,000. She will invest USD $800 in the purchase of three calves and USD $200 to buy vitamins, medecine for deworming, vaccines, salt, minerals and molasses. She plans to sell the cattle at one of the many local auctions. Silvia is part of the Florencia community bank, one of the more than 100 member organisations of EDESA in Costa Rica. This will be her first loan as a member, but she already has savings with the bank. She hopes to improve her business with this loan and thus achieve a better quality of life for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy three calves, medecine and vaccines.

location.town: San Rafael de Florencia de San Carlos

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Demetria

texts.es: Demetria de 36 años, vive tranquila su soltería, alquilada en una casa cerca de su puesto de trabajo y aunque no cuenta con energía eléctrica, no se desanima e insiste en salir adelante con el negocio que ha emprendido. Sin ayuda de nadie, empujando su carrito, Demetria sale todas las noches a vender sus deliciosos salchimotes (comida hecha a base de mote frito y rodajas de salchichas), los cuales son degustados por las personas que pasan por su puesto, muchos de los cuales llegan a comerse hasta 3 o 4 platos, su negocio es muy rentable, debido a los bajos precios que tienen sus salchimotes. Ella disfruta cuando sus clientes alaban su deliciosa sazón, pero no le gusta tener que soportar el congelante frió que hace por la noches. Ya lleva 10 años en este negocio y ha decidido que es hora de mejorarlo, en el futuro quiere vender más salchimotes  y tener más ingresos, para mejorar su vida. Demetria es una de las socias más amables de su banco comunal, siempre es muy activa en sus reuniones y ahora se encuentra en su segundo préstamo, ella siempre ha pagado todas sus cuotas a tiempo, aunque para ello tenga que amanecerse vendiendo salchimote. Con el dinero del préstamo, Demetria pretende renovar su carrito de salchimote, y comprar más ingredientes para la preparación de su deliciosa comida, adquirir todo esto le costara alrededor de 800 nuevos soles y espera con esto tener un mejor futuro.
texts.en:
Demetria, 36 years old, is unmarried and lives a tranquil life, lodged in a house near her workplace. Although the house does not yet have electricity, she doesn't get discouraged and is determined to get ahead with the business she started. Without anyone's help, Demetria goes out pushing her little cart every night to sell her delicious salchimotes (a food made of fried corn and sliced sausages), which are sampled by passersby. Many people end up eating three or four plates. Her business is doing very well, thanks to her low-priced salchimotes. She loves it when customers praise their delicious flavor, but she doesn't like having to endure the freezing cold at night. She's worked in this business for 10 years and has decided to improve it. In the future she'd like to send more salchimotes and earn a larger income in order to improve her life. Demetria is one of the friendliest members of her "banco comunal" (communal bank); she's always very active in meetings and is now on her second loan. She has always made her payments on time, even if she's had to stay up all night selling salchimote to do it. With the money from this loan, Demetria wants to refurbish her salchimote cart and buy more ingredients for preparing her delicious food. She can manage all this at a cost of about 800 nuevos soles, and hopes in that way to have a better future.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Refurbish the cart she uses to sell food

loans.name: Carlos Luis

texts.es:
Carlos Luis G. A. es un señor de 65 años de edad que vive en Costa Rica, en la comunidad de Grifo Alto de Puriscal. Está casado y vive con su esposa y su hija que se llama Marisela G.. Tiene una pequeña finca en la cual hay una naciente de agua en la parte más alta.
Grifo Alto es una comunidad rural que se ubica aproximadamente a una hora de San José que es la capital de Costa Rica. Queda en las montañas y tiene una vista muy linda de valles, ríos y montañas que miran a la costa pacífica de Costa Rica. Grifo Alto queda sobre la carretera que va hacia las playas por lo tanto muchos turistas paran ahí a comer, o simplemente disfrutar de los paisajes y el ambiente rural. En la zona hay muchas fincas pequeñas que se dedican tanto a la agricultura como a la ganadería. Anteriormente se sembraba mucho tabaco pero luego los precios bajaron y la gente buscó otras opciones.
Don Carlos aprovechó la naciente de agua que hay en su finca y construyó un estanque para criar tilapias. Por su edad y lo difícil del terreno tardó casi dos años para hacer el estanque utilizando sólo un pico y una pala porque en el lugar no puede entrar maquinaria porque es muy inclinado. Don Carlos dice que le costó mucho hacerlo especialmente sacar las piedras más grandes. 
Una vez hecho el estanque comenzó a criar tilapias. Cuando crecieron las primeras comenzó a venderlas con una hielera a la orilla de la carretera que pasa frente a su finca. Luego de un año, como el negocio iba bien pensó construir un negocio pequeño y tuvo la idea de cocinar la tilapia y venderla preparada en platos con comida típica. El plato típico en Costa Rica se conoce como “el casado” e incluye arroz, frijoles, tortillas, plátanos, ensalada y tilapia u otra carne. En su negocio participan su esposa y su hija quienes atienden el restaurante.
Al día de hoy el Ministerio de Salud le está pidiendo varios requisitos para ampliar el local y dar un mejor servicio a sus clientes. Por esta razón está solicitando un microcrédito de $ 540 que le permita comprar madera, pintura, clavos y otros materiales para ampliar el local. 
Don Carlos es socio de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal de Grifo Alto de Puriscal la cual es una de las organizaciones comunales socias de EDESA. Actualmente él no cuenta con préstamos pero sí ha realizado inversiones de capital en esta organización.
texts.en:
Carlos Luis G. A. is 65 years old and lives in Costa Rica in the community of Grifo Alto de Puriscal. He is married and lives with his wife and daughter who is named Marisela G.. He has a small farm, in which there is a spring in the higher part. Grifo Alto is a rural community that is situated approximately one hour from San Jose, the capital of Costa Rica. It is situated in the mountains, and it has a beautiful view of the valleys, rivers and mountains that look out over the coast of Costa Rica. Grifo Alto is along the highway that goes to the beach, and for this reason, many tourists stop there to eat or simply to enjoy themselves in the countryside and rural surroundings. In this area, there are many small farms that are dedicated to raising cattle. Before that, they raised tobacco, but then the price went down and people looked for other options. Don Carlos improved the spring that is on his farm and constructed a pond where he raises tilapi. Because of his age and the difficulty of the terrain, almost two years passed making the pool, utilizing only a pick and shovel because the place is so steep that machinery can’t get there. Don Carlos says that it cost a lot to make, especially moving the very large rocks. One time he finished making the pool and began raising tilapia. When the first ones were born, he began to sell them in an ice bucket along the edge of the highway that passes in front of his farm. After one year, when the business was going well, he thought he would make a little more business, and he had the idea of cooking the tilpapia and selling it prepared on plates with customary foods. The customary food in Costa Rica is known as “the marriage” and includes rice, beans, tortillas, plantains, salad and tilapia or another meat. His wife helps in this business, and his daughter works in the restaurant part. At the present time, the Minister of Health is asking that various requirements be met for improving business and giving better service to customers. For this reason, arlos is asking for $540 that will enable him to buy wood, paint, nails, and other materials to improve the location. Don Carlos is a member of the Communal Credit Corporation of Grifo Alto of Puriscal, which is one of the communal organizations of EDESA. Actually, he is not counting on a loan, but he has seen the value of investment capital from this organization.

Translated from Spanish by Misty McNally, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Materials to improve his restaurant

loans.name: Olman Quesada

texts.es:
Don Olman Quesada V. es un señor de 35 años de edad. Vive en una casa propia con su esposa y dos hijos. Es un productor de leche desde hace tres años. Anteriormente se dedicaba con su familia al ganado de engorde (carne) pero poco a poco ha ido cambiando al ganado de leche lo cual le ha ayudado a sacar adelante a su familia.
Don Olman vive en El Sauce de Santa Teresita de Turrialba. Es una pequeña comunidad rural de unos dos mil habitantes. Sus pobladores se dedican principalmente a la producción de leche y siembra de café. Tiene un relieve irregular y mucho del terreno se mantiene como bosque tropical húmedo. La comunidad tiene paisajes muy pintorescos que combinan el bosque tropical con dos lindas lagunas, plantaciones de café y lecherías. 
El Sauce se localiza aproximadamente a hora y media en bus de Turrialba, el centro de comercio más cercano, sin embargo varias veces al año, el camino se vuelve intransitable por las lluvias que caen en la zona. Este es sin duda uno de los principales desafíos para la comunidad. Cuando no existían actividades muchas personas optaron por salir a buscar trabajos en Turrialba o en fincas bananeras ubicadas en el Atlántico de Costa Rica. Actualmente los precios del café y la leche han mejorado por lo tanto los vecinos buscan cómo invertir en proyectos en la misma zona.
Don Olman comenzó sembrando un pequeño sector de su finca con pastos para picar y así darle un mejor alimento a sus vacas de leche. Su idea es ir mejorando la calidad del alimento que da a sus vacas para producir más leche. Además quiere mantener los costos bajos utilizando alimentos que puede producir en la misma finca en lugar de tener que comprar concentrados u otros alimentos más caros. Actualmente el pasto lo corta y pica a mano utilizando un machete.
Don Olman desea sacar un préstamo de ¢500.000 ($900) para comprar más semilla de pasto y una máquina para picar pasto. Él dice que si logra tener más alimento para el ganado dentro de la misma finca podrá mejorar el rendimiento actual y así tener más ganancias. El préstamo lo va a sacar pensando en mejorar la calidad de vida de sus dos hijos y su esposa. Sí hay más ingresos se beneficia toda la familia.
Don Olman es cliente de la Asociación de Productores de El Sauce, una organización local socia de la microfinanciera EDESA. Gracias a su vinculación con esta organización ha obtenido ya cuatro  préstamos y todos los ha cancelado satisfactoriamente. El cuenta que al principio no tenía terreno ni vacas pero que a través de su vinculación con la organización ha ido sacando préstamos que ha ido pagando y así a cambiado su vida y que ahora él se considera un microempresario.
texts.en:
Don Olman Quesada V. is 35 years old; he lives in his own house with his wife and two children. He has been producing milk for three years. Previously, he and his family were raised cattle, but little by little he has shifted to dairy, which has helped him to move his family forward. Don Olman lives in El Sauce de Santa Teresita in Turrialba. It's a small rural community of 2,000 residents. The settlers all work mainly in milk production and coffee planting. It has a rugged terrain and much of the ground is damp tropical forest. The community has very picturesque scenery: tropical forest combined with two pretty lakes, coffee plantations, and dairy farms. El Sauce is located about 1.5 hours by bus from Turrialba, the closest commercial center, however several times a year, the road becomes impassable from the rains that fall in the region. This is without doubt one of the main challenges for the community. When there were not a lot of activities, many people opted to leave and search for work in Turrialba or on banana farms located on the Atlantic in Costa Rica. Presently, the price of coffee and milk has improved, hence the neighbors are looking to invest in projects in their own region. Don Olman started planting a small area of his farm with pasture which has given him better food for his dairy cows. Moreover, he wants to keep his costs low by using food that he can produce on his own farm instead of needing to buy extract and other food that is more expensive. Presently, his grass is cut and picked by hand using a machete. Don Olman wants to take out of loan of ¢500.000 ($900) to buy more grass seed and a machine to pick the grass. He says he will achieve more food for the cows within his own farm and he will be able to improve his output and make more money. The loan he is going to take will improve the quality of life of his two children and his wife. If there are more earnings, it benefits the whole family. Don Olman is a client of the Association of Producers of El Sauce, a local organization that partners with the microfinance institution EDESA. Thanks to his connection with this organization, he has already received four loans, and all have been repaid satisfactorily. When Don Olman started he had no land or cows, but through his connection to the organization he has taken loans and repaid them, and this has changed his life, so that now he is considered a micro-entrepreneur.

Translated from Spanish by Cara Gutterman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Grass seed and a machine to pick the grass

location.town: El Sauce de Santa Teresita de Turrialba

loans.name: Hilda

texts.es: Hilda es una mujer de 29 años muy trabajadora, que pone todo de su parte para salir adelante, trabaja desde los 15 años, puesto que siempre tuvo en mente el querer mejorar su vida y lograr su independencia. El tiempo a pasado en la vida de Hilda, son ya más 12 años que lleva vendiendo sal a sus habituales cliente, muchos de los cuales la acompañan desde que abrió su pequeña tiendita, lo que quiere es hacer crecer su negocio, comprando mayor número de sacos de sal, ya que sus pedidos son tantos que por lo general se queda sin mercadería, a ella le gusta el comercio, es una vendedora por naturaleza y es muy persuasiva vendiendo su producto a las personas que concurren a su local, aunque sufre mucho trasladando los sacos de sal hasta su tienda. Hilda trabaja para tener una vida digna, en la cual pueda tener todo lo necesario, para vivir tranquila su vejes. Es la primera vez que accede a un préstamo en Microfinanzas PRISMA, su banco comunal la apoya y quiere que salga adelante, ya que es la socias que más se preocupa en que todos tengan su parte del préstamo. Hilda planea incrementar su mercadería, comprando más cantidad de sacos de sal, el costo de esta adquisición, será de quinientos nuevos soles, e invertirá el resto en arreglar su tienda, para atender mejor a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Hilda is a hardworking woman, 29 years old, who makes every effort to get ahead. She has been working since she was 15 years old, since she's always wanted to improve her life and be self-sufficient. Time has passed, and now Hilda's been selling salt to her regular customers, many of whom have been with her since she first opened her little shop, for more than 12 years. Hilda wants to grow her business, buying a greater number of bags of salt, since at this point she receives so many orders that she usually sells out. She likes commerce and is a natural salesperson. She's very persuasive when she's selling her product to the people who come to her store, although it's difficult for her to carry the bags of salt to her store. Hilda works so she can have a dignified life where she has everything she needs, and live peacefully in her old age. This is the first time she's requested a loan from Microfinanzas PRISMA. Her "banco comunal" (communal bank) supports her and wants her to get ahead, since she's the member who cares most that everyone else gets their share of the loan. Hilda plans to increase her stock, buying more bags of salt. This will cost 500 nuevos soles, and she will invest the rest in repairing her store in order to better serve her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her store

loans.name: Martha

texts.es: Martha es una mujer soltera, que a sus 30 años siempre ha luchado por salir adelante, quiere formar una familia, pero es conciente que necesita tener un buen sustento económico antes para darle a sus hijos un buen futuro. Para comer bien en Juliaca, se tiene que visitar el restaurante de Martha, el cual se ha convertido en uno de los más concurridos de la ciudad, debido a la gran sazón que le pone a sus comidas. Ella ya tiene 5 años en este negocio y ha decidido que quiere ampliarlo, incrementando el número de mesas que actualmente tiene. A Martha le gusta cocinar y siempre lo hace con mucha dedicación, pero le disgusta servir y llevar los platos de comida a los clientes porque tiene que hacerlo sola, ya que no cuenta con el dinero para pagarle a un ayudante, aun así no se desanima y quiere salir adelante para en el futuro llevar una buena vida. Ya estando en su segundo préstamo, Ana que siempre paga todas sus cuotas a tiempo, ha decidido mejorar su negocio y siente que tiene el respaldo de los socios  de su banco comunal, en el cual es muy querida. Con el préstamo adquirido en Microfinanzas PRISMA, Martha ha decidido comprar  5 mesas con sus respectivas sillas, que le costarán entre 800 a 1000 nuevos soles, ella está dispuesta a poner plata de su parte, con tal de mejorar y ampliar su negocio.
texts.en:
Martha is an unmarried woman, 30 years old, who has always struggled to get ahead. She'd like to start a family, but she knows she needs to have good economic means of support before she can offer her children a good future. For eating well in Juliaca, a visit to Martha's restaurant is a must. It has become one of the most popular spots in the city because of the great flavor she gives her food. She's been working in this business five years and wants to expand it, increasing the number of tables she currently has. Martha likes to cook and always does it with great dedication, but she doesn't like serving and carrying the plates of food to her customers because she has to do it by herself, since she doesn't have the money to pay someone to help her. Still, she doesn't become discouraged and wants to get ahead in order to live a better life in the future. Now on her second loan, Ana always makes her payments on time. She has decided to improve her business and feels that she has the support of the members of her "banco communal" (communal bank), where she is well-liked. With a loan from Microfinanzas PRISMA, Martha has decided to buy five tables and the chairs to go with them, which will cost between 800 and 1000 nuevos soles. She is ready to invest her own money in improving and expanding her business.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy furniture for her restaurant

loans.name: Rocío

texts.es: Rocío es una Joven soltera de 22 años, vive en una casa alquilada con sus padres, a los cuales quiere ayudar con los gastos del mes, puesto que no han faltado las veces en que la carencia de dinero los han puesto en problemas. Endulzando el paladar de sus clientes, Rocío a sabido progresar en su vida, las delicias azucarados que vende en su triciclo, la han convertido en la reina de los postres, a los cuales sus clientes no se pueden resistir y siempre terminan comiéndose más de uno, ella disfruta de preguntar a sus clientes si es de su agrado el postre que le sirvió y no se molesta si le dan unos consejitos para mejorarlos. Lleva 3 años en este negocio y le es muy difícil tener que caminar tanto para poder vender sus postres, a Rocío en el futuro le gustaría tener un puestito donde vender sus productos y así poco a poco ir ayudando a sus padres con los gastos del hogar, para que ellos ya no tengan que trabajar tanto. Rocío desea pagar sus cuotas puntualmente, siendo este su primer préstamo, ella no tiene dudas en poder lograrlo, sabe que tiene el apoyo de su banco comunal y es por eso que se preocupa en el bienestar de sus socios. Con el préstamo adquirido, planea comprar un carrito para postres, que le costara aproximadamente 900 nuevos soles, con el resto del dinero quiere comprar los ingredientes necesarios para preparar sus deliciosos postres.
texts.en:
Rocío is a young, unmarried woman, 22 years old. She lives in a rented house with her parents, whom she wants to help with their monthly expenses, since a lack of money has caused problems a number of times. Tickling her customers' palates, Rocío has known how to get ahead in life, and the sugary treats she sells from her three-wheeled cart have made her the queen of desserts. Her customers can't resist and always end up eating more than one. She likes asking her customers if they enjoyed the sweet they just ate, and she doesn't mind if they give her some tips on improving them. She's been in this business for three years and it's hard for her to have to walk so much to sell her treats. In the future, Rocío would like to have a little stall to sell her products from, and in that way gradually assist her parents with domestic expenses so they don't have to work so much. Rocío plans to make her payments on time. This is her first loan, and she is sure she will be able to pay it back. She knows that she has the support of her "banco comunal" (communal bank), and she worries about the other members' wellbeing. With this loan, she plans to buy a little pastry cart, which will cost about 900 nuevos soles. With the rest of the money she would like to buy the ingredients needed to prepare her delicious desserts.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a cart for her business

loans.name: Yovana
