For the past year, she has worked selling athletic clothing to friends and family but especially to athletes that she finds while visiting various gyms. She decided to start this business in order to help her progress and to grow her income. For the past five years, Noemi has tended to her own beauty parlor. Due to her studies in cosmetology, she had decided to open the doors of her home to offer hair cuts and styling first to her friends, and later to other customers. Thanks to the amount of space in her beauty parlor, Noemi also sells makeup and cosmetics in general. In the future, she hopes to also have the assistance of her daughter who will also study cosmetology; this will allow her to expand the shop and put up a new store in the market to sell clothing.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of athletic clothing to sell

loans.name: Gilbert

texts.en:
Gilbert N. is married to Mary and blessed with seven children. Three of the children are under 15 years of age. He is a very hardworking man. He has faced numerous financial difficulties, especially when he lost his job and was not able to meet the family needs and educate his children. He also lost his lovely daughter who was by his side, supporting him to meet the family needs.

Gilbert joined GHAPE in 2003 and made a loan of 20000 FRS, which he invested in poultry. As the years went by and his business grew, he went further and added pig farming as one of his businesses. N. is a carpenter by profession and he will be investing his loan in furniture; selling of planks, making chairs, cupboards, tables, beds and other item from wood. His business will succeed because he has been doing this particular trade for some time in his community. He also plans to continue his pig farm and will used part of the loan to buy piglets, feed and medication to keep the farm running.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Purchase of planks, cloth, nails, and piglets

loans.name: Amalia

texts.es:
A la vivienda de la señora Amalia R. le esta haciendo falta los acabados del exterior e interior, pero por el momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para poder llevar acabo la mejora. Es por eso que esta solicitando un crédito para poder realizar lo mas pronto posible la mejora y así su casa va estar mucho mejor. 
Doña Amalia es una persona ya mayor de edad tiene poco tiempo que se quedo viuda con ella vive un hijo quien es que le ayudad en los gastos.
texts.en:
Amalia R.' home still lacks the finishing touches on both the outside and inside, but currently she does not have enough money to finish the home improvement. She is seeking a loan in order to do so as soon as possible so that her home is in better condition. Amalia is an elderly woman who was widowed a short time ago; now her son lives with her and helps her with her household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Finish the outside and inside of her home

loans.name: Rossana Alicia

texts.es:
A Rossana siempre le ha gustado el negocio, en cualquier rubro se ha sentido bien; sin embargo confeccionar ropa es lo que más le gusta a ella. Es por ello que luego de que su hermano le concediera permiso para poder utilizar sus máquinas textiles ella y un familiar se dedicaron a confeccionar ropa de invierno para vender. 

Hace cuatro años que vende prendas de polar y casacas. Al inicio ella se dedicaba a comprar ropa a un bajo precio y a revenderlas en el mercado, pero se dio cuenta que si confeccionaba su propia ropa podía generar mayores ingresos.

Además de su negocio de ropa, desde hace ocho meses también vende lencería y vajillas para la cocina con el fin de solventar sus gastos durante el verano. Eventualmente, trabaja para una imprenta armando distintos tipos de manualidades. Esto lo hace al por mayor y con la ayuda de sus hijas de 14 y 15 años.
texts.en:
Rossana has always liked business; although she feels comfortable doing many types of work, she likes making clothes the most. So when Rossana's brother gave her permission to use his textile machines, she and a relative began making winter clothes to sell. She has now been selling jackets and fleece jackets for four years. At first she bought clothes wholesale to sell in the market, but then she realized she could earn more money selling clothes she made. Aside from her winter clothing business, she has been selling lingerie and kitchen dish sets for the past eight months, to cover her expenses during the summer. She might also work at a printing press doing different assembly jobs with the help of her daughters, who are 14- and 15-years old.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cloth to make sheets

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en: Adwoa K. is 55 years old. She is widowed and has six children to cater for. Two of her children are girls and four are boys. Almost all of her children are currently out of school and are living independently. She lives with her daughters in a family house in Koforidua, a business/farming town in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. Most of the inhabitants are engaged in trading and farming activities. Adwoa deals in cooking utensils. She says she procures her goods from big shops in Kumasi. She sells in a small shop in the local market and also hawks to houses in her community. Adwoa has been in business for over five years. She desires to use the loan to expand her business by buying utensils in bulk to be able to trek to nearby markets to do business. She aspires to sponsor some of her grandchildren to the university level of education.

loans.use: To buy utensils for resale

loans.name: Marie Chantal

texts.en:
Greetings from Marie Chantal U. in Gatsata sector, Gasabo District, Kigali (the capital city of Rwanda)! Marie Chantal is 32 years old, married with 2 children and raising 1 orphan.

Marie Chantal started her business one year ago. Marie Chantal operates a cell phone accessories shop in town where she sells various cell phone accessories such as cell phone batteries, cell phones cases, cell phone covers, cell phone chargers, face plates, screen protectors, and many more.

This entrepreneur is requesting a loan worth 500,000 Rwf, which will help her to expand her business. Marie Chantal believes that once she gets this loan, her shop will become bigger and her profit will increase.

loans.use: Expansion of her business

loans.name: Akua

texts.en: Akua S. is 37 years old. She is married and has given birth to five children, two of whom are boys and three girls. Two of her children are currently in school. The other three are yet to start school. She lives with the two children who are already in school in a rented apartment in Koforidua, a small town not very far from Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. The husband, a farmer, lives with the other children in the northern part of the country. Akua works to support her husband. Akua trades in bananas. Most of the women in the community trade in bananas and other fruits. She buys unripe bananas from farmers in the nearby villages, stores them until ripe and then sells them. She sells to retailers in her community in the local market. Akua has been in business for three years. It has been her dream to save enough money to support her husband in taking care of the family. She wants a loan to procure bananas in bulk so she can maximize her profit margin.

loans.use: To procure bananas for resale.

loans.name: Salvador

texts.es:
La señor Salvador A. acaba de adquirir su vivienda por medio de un crédito gubernamental. Pero le están haciendo falta las protecciones y la barda alrededor de la casa. 
  Don Salvador está solicitando un préstamo para poder realizar la mejora lo más pronto posible. Ya que él trabaja todo el día y su familia se queda solo en la casa y quiere la seguridad para ellos. (En la foto no aparece el señor Salvador, si no aparece su esposa e hijo).
texts.en:
Salvador A. just bought a house using government loans, but he still needs to build a wall around the house. Salvador is requesting a loan to make the improvement as soon as possible, since he works all day while his family stays at home and he wants the house to be safe. (Only his wife and son appear in the picture).

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction of a wall for safety

loans.name: Nicole

texts.fr: Dame A. Nicole est née le 15 Août 1982 à Cotonou.Mariée à LOKO Jacques, menuisier ébeniste de formation,elle a une petite fille du nom de Fraichnelle. Elle a fréquenté jusqu'en classe de seconde avant d'abandonner de son propre gré.Après l'abandon des classes,elle s'est mise à faire le commerce d'oignons avec l'aide financière de sa mère.Ensuite ,elle vendit de piment frais au grand marché de Cotonou.Elle abandonna toutes ces activités au profit de la vente de sacs de charbons depuis 3ans.C'est dans le souci de renforcer son commerce de charbon que dame A. Nicole sollicite ce prêt pour s'approvisionner uniquement en sacs de charbons.
texts.en:
Ms. Nicole A. was born on August 15, 1982 in Cotonou and is married to Mr. Jacques LOKO, a carpenter trained in working with ebony. She has a young girl named Fraichnelle. Ms. A. attended school through the 10th grade before deciding to drop out. Next, she sold fresh chili peppers at the grand marketplace of Cotonou but then abandoned that work three years ago in order to sell charcoal. With the concern of bolstering her commerce, she is requesting this loan to supply herself only with sacks of charcoal.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: A supply of 75 sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Efrain

texts.es:
Con treinta y cinco años cumplidos Efraín es una persona que ha hecho mucho en su vida y aún tiene mucho más por hacer. Padre de dos hijos aún menores y casado hace diez años aproximadamente, Efraín siempre ha velado por el bienestar de su familia.

Hace más de quince años, Efraín y su hermana estudiaron un curso de confección de tejidos gracias a un programa del estado denominado PROJOVEN. Con sus conocimientos sobre la confección de ropa hoy junto con su hermana maneja un pequeño negocio textil. Hace cuatro años produce ropa para venderlas en diferentes mercados y por la temporada de invierno especialmente.

Por otro lado, Efraín también se desempeña como maestro de obra contratista encargándose de la construcción de obras civiles, teniendo bajo su cargo personas trabajando para él. Por lo mismo, y con el único fin de progresar hace un año inicio sus estudios universitarios en la carrera de Ingeniería civil, carrera que estudia en las noches, en el poco tiempo libre que le resta. Al finalizar sus estudios tiene planes de formar su empresa de construcción.

Por si fuera poco, junto con su esposa ha iniciado un nuevo proyecto. Hace dos meses por la temporada de verano se animaron a producir y vender al por mayor un tipo de helado llamado “zambito”. Con el cual tiene muchos planes para poder mejorar la distribución y aumentar el número de producción.
texts.en:
At 35 years old Efraín is a person who has done a lot in his life but still has a lot left to do. He is the father of two young children and has been married for approximately ten years. Efraín has always seen to the well being of his family. More than fifteen years ago Efraín and his sister took a course on textile manufacturing thanks to a state program called PROJOVEN. Using their knowledge of clothes manufacturing, Efraín and his sister operate a small textile business. For four years they have produced clothes to sell in different markets, specializing in winter clothing. In addition, Efraín works as a contractor for civil construction projects, managing a group of people who work under him. At the same time, in order to get ahead, he started taking classes at a university one year ago and is studying to be a civil engineer. He conducts his studies at night, in the little free time he has. Once he finishes his studies he plans to start a construction business. As if this wasn't enough, he and his wife have started a new project. Two months ago they decided start a business for the summer months in which they would produce and sell at wholesale a type of ice cream called "zambito". They have many plans of how they can improve distribution and increase the production numbers.

Translated from Spanish by Matthew Raimondi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raw materials and tools for a new ice cream business

loans.name: Abena

texts.en: Abena K. is 49 years old. She is widowed and has six children, three of whom are boys and three of whom are girls. One of the children has completed the senior high school. The others are in the primary and the junior high school. She lives with the family in Koforidua, a small town not very far from Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. It is entirely a farming and commercial town. Abena works to support her husband. She trades in bananas. Most of the women in the community trade in bananas and other fruits. She buys plantains from farmers in the nearby villages and sells in her community. She sells to retailers in her community in the local market. Most of her customers are food vendors. Abena has been in business for six years. It is Abena’s dream to save enough money to support her husband and take care of the family. She wants a loan to procure plantains in bulk so she can maximize her profit margin.

loans.use: To procure plantains for resale.

loans.name: Martha

texts.es:
Martha, de treinta y ocho años de edad, se desempeña como enfermera cuidado pacientes particulares los días domingos, trabajo que sus estudios de enfermería le permitieron conseguir. Actualmente, durante todos los días se encarga de vender productos de belleza por catálogo. Hasta hace poco tenía un puesto en el mercado donde vendía postres, golosinas y jugos, lamentablemente el mercado fue clausurado y tuvo que abandonar su negocio.

Junto con su esposo, quien trabaja como taxista, comparten los gastos de la casa y de sus dos pequeños hijos. Sin embargo, en la medida de lo posible, por ahora esta ahorrando parte de su dinero para poder comprar mas adelante una maquina de coser e implementar un taller de confección en su casa.
texts.en:
Martha is 38 years old. On Sundays she works as a nurse caring for private patients, a job she has because of her studies in nursing. These days she also works every day selling beauty products through a catalog. Until recently, Martha had a stall in the market where she sold desserts, candies, and juices, but unfortunately the market was closed down and she had to abandon her business. Martha and her husband, who works as a taxi driver, both share the household expenses and the costs of rearing their two small children. For now, however, Martha is saving her part of their money as much as possible so that she can eventually purchase a sewing machine and set up a dressmaking shop in their home.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing beauty products

loans.name: Attaa

texts.en: Attaa A. is 34 years old. She is married and has given birth to six children – one boy and five girls. Almost all of her children are in school. The last born is yet to start. She lives together with her children and husband in Koforidua, a small town near Offinso. Koforidua is a business and farming community in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. Attaa’s husband is a farmer. She works to support her husband to provide for the family. She is a fish monger. She sells in a shed in the local market square. She also treks to nearby markets to sell. Attaa procures her goods from big time fish mongers in the Western Region and the coastal areas of the country. Attaa has been in business for six years. According to her, most of her customers are food vendors in her community. She wants a loan to buy fish in bulk to make more profit so she can help her children in school.

loans.use: To buy smoked fish for resale.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary K. is 53 years old. She is married and given birth to seven children. She sells porridge and kose at her neighborhood. She lives and trades at Abofour in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Mary loves selling these foods, a business through which she obtains her daily bread to cater for her household. 

Kose is prepared from milled beans and soybeans with pepper, and afterwards it is fried and taken with the porridge. Porridge is one of the local foods enjoyed popularly as breakfast. It is prepared from milled maize or millet grains, boiled and taken with sugar, milk and bread or kose. With a large customer base, she wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, millet, sugar, beans and milk to increase production. She hopes to raise good income to support her kids in school. 

Mary belongs to a village bank called ‘Jacob’. She hopes to receive GHS 500 to make business progress. And she would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials like bags of maize, millet, sugar, and milk etc.

loans.name: Vera

texts.en:
Vera S. is 37 years old and married. She has seven children and they are currently in school. She lives with her husband and their children in a family house at Abofour. Abofour is a busy market town in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. She enjoys trading so much that she started trading in her infancy when she stayed with her parents. But she has been trading in yams for over four years. Through this business, she has saved part to provide for the educational needs of her two kids who are in the senior high school.

She says she buys her goods from the small towns nearby and sometimes treks to Kintampo in the Brong Ahafo region when there is scarcity of yams for sale. She then sells her yams at the local market mostly to travelers who ply that road. Vera at times buys beans, bunch of banana or any other cereals depending on situation on the grounds. She hopes to increase the quantity of food stuffs that she buys at each trip so as to cut down on her frequent transportation and be able to supply to a sizeable market. She belongs to a village bank called ‘Naomi’. She also hopes to receive GHS 800 to make business progress by restocking her inventory. This would enable her to save more to support her husband in taking care of the home. Vera has registered with the Ghana national health insurance and the family which takes care of their medical bills free of charge depending on the condition.

loans.use: To buy yams in bulk for resale.

loans.name: Asanji

texts.en:
Asanji is married to Theresia and they are blessed with six children. He has faced challenges in life such as ill health and poverty. Faced with all these challenges, it was not comfortable for Asanji to cope with the family needs. Asanji was introduced to GHAPE in the year 2003.

Asanji received his first loan of 20,000 FRS and invested in pigs, while he started the repayment promptly. Given a new loan he plans to rent a field of raffia palms to tap for palm sap which he will use to produce palm wine, commonly call “white mimbo”. "White mimbo" is a drink that many people in the country love drinking during ceremonies and on special occasions since it is inexpensive.

He has hope that the business will succeed because of the experience he has in the business and he has been doing this business for quite a long time, inheriting the process from his parents.This business he is doing will help those in his community by providing drink during ceremonies. He plans to use the profit from the loan to pay his children's school fees, save more to carry on bigger investments, and complete his child's apprenticeship fees. Asanji plans to start repayment on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Renting of raffia bush

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana D. is 30 years old. She is divorced but has one child, a boy who is currently in the basic school. She lives with the child in a rented apartment in Koforidua, a small town not very far from Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. It is entirely a farming and commercial town. Christiana works very hard to take care of her child. She trades in bananas and oranges. Fruit selling is a business run by many women in the community. She buys bags of oranges and unripe banana from farmers in the nearby villages, stores the banana until ripe and then sells them. She sells to retailers in her community in the local market. She at times resorts to other types of fruits. Christiana has been in business for over ten years. It has been her dreams to save enough money to support her child in school. She wants a loan to procure banana and oranges in bulk to increase her profit margin.

loans.use: To procure bananas and oranges to sell.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama N. is a 40 year old woman. She is married and has five children. All her kids are in school. She lives with her husband in her matrimonial home, at Abofour a suburb of Offinso in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She is an achiever and a resourceful young woman. She loves selling goods, the business through which she makes a living. 

Ama has traded in oranges and crates of eggs in Abofour market for more than ten years now. She treks to surrounding villages in the Central part of Ghana to purchase bulk stock of oranges and crates of eggs from the farmers and to retail to her customers. For lack of adequate working capital, she is not able to pick enough stock to make enough profit to support her family. She wants to use part of the profit to support her kid’s education.
  
With the loan, she wants to purchase bulk supply of oranges and crates of egg to enable her scale up her sales. She believes the loan would enable her to save more income to support her business growth. Ama belongs to a village bank called ‘Fear Not’. She also hopes to receive GHS 500 to make business progress by restocking her inventory. This would enable her save more to support the husband in taking care of the home.

loans.use: To purchase oranges and eggs in bulk for resale.

loans.name: Mariama

texts.en:
Mariama A. is 37 year old married and mother of two kids who are in school. She has been a food vendor for two years. She prepares and sells rice and stew and she has also added beans and gari to it. It is a delicacy many Ghanaian enjoy everyday either as breakfast, lunch or dinner. She also sells fried rice. Her business is doing well and she wants to expand her operations to serve more customers. With the loan, she wants to buy more beans, grains, vegetables, rice and assorted meat for her operation. She hopes this loan would help her increase her savings to improve her family well-being. She would be very grateful for that assistance. 

She belongs to a village bank called ‘Jacob’. She also hopes to receive GHS 500 to make business progress by restocking her inventory. This would enable her save more to support her husband in taking care of the home.

loans.use: To buy bags of dried maize grains, rice, vegetables, assorted meat, etc.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en: Lydia N. is 30 years old. She is married and has given birth to four children, two of whom are boys and two of whom are girls. One of the children is in the junior high school. The others are in the primary school. She lives with the family in Koforidua, a small town not very far from Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. It is entirely a farming and commercial town. Lydia works to support her husband. Her husband is a commercial driver. He conveys goods and people from and to Koforidua and nearby market centers. Lydia trades in bananas. Most of the women in the community trade in bananas and other fruits. She buys unripe banana from farmers in the nearby villages, stores them until ripe and then sells them. She sells to retailers in her community in the local market. She says she also treks to nearby markets to sell. Lydia has been in business for five years. It is her dream to save enough money to support her husband in taking care of the family. She wants a loan to procure bananas in bulk so she can maximize her profit margin.

loans.use: To buy bananas for resale.

loans.name: Akwasi

texts.en:
Akwasi A. is a thirty two year old single father with one child. He lives with his child and younger brothers at Abofour in the Ashanti region of Ghana.

Akwasi has been a carpenter for the past six years and carpentry has been his main occupation and sole source of income for his family. He owns a carpentry shop where he manufactures all kinds of furniture. He produces dinning tables, sitting room chairs etc... He has recently begun selling grocery products like sugar, evaporated milk etc...from his shop.

Akwasi's lack of adequate working capital does not allow him to pre-finance most of the orders from his customers. This situation slows down his work because he has to wait for funds from his customers before any work can begin. He requests this loan to enable him to procure useful working tools and furnishing materials like polish, glue, sand paper etc... to improve his efficiency. He believes this will improve his income and ensure a better living for his family. Akwasi belongs to a village bank called ‘Fear Not’.

loans.use: To procure useful working tools and furnishing materials like polish, glue, sand paper etc.

loans.name: Fati

texts.en: Fati S. is a forty five years old widow and has given birth to eleven children. Unfortunately, 5 of the children have passed away. Four of her remaining children are males and two are daughters, all of whom are in school. She lives with the children in a rented apartment in Koforidua, a small town not very far from Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. Fati works very hard to provide for her children. She is a farmer and trader of banana and cassava. She buys cassava and unripe banana from farmers in her locality and from the nearby villages and resells to retailers in her community local market. Fati has been in business for six years. It is Fati’s desire to save enough money to support her children in their academics. She is requesting a loan to procure banana and cassava in bulk so she can maximize her profit margin.

loans.use: To procure banana and cassava for resale.

loans.name: Antoinette

texts.fr: Agée de 38 ans,dame H. Antoinette est originaire de Ganvié, village lacustre. Elle a trois enfants: Rosaline,Casimir, et Simplice.  Elle n'a jamais été à l'école et n'a apprit aucun métier.Mais,elle fut initiée à la vente de poissons frais par sa tutrice dans son adolescence.C'est cela qu'elle fit jusqu'à se marier.Il y a 5 ans,elle a diversifié son activité avec la vente de nourriture(riz, et pâte de maïs accompagnés de sauce).Actuellement,elle veut renforcer  cette dernière activité pour mieux satisfaire la demande  de sa clientèle.Elle compte s'approvisionner en riz, maïs  et gari.
texts.en:
Ms. Antoinette H., age 38, is from the lakeside village of Ganvié and has three children: Rosaline, Casimir, and Simplice. She never attended school nor learned a trade. But as an adolescent, she was initiated by her tutor in how to sell fresh fish. She did this until she got married. Five years ago, she diversified her business by selling prepared foods (rice; corn mash with sauce). Presently she wants to bolster her business to satisfy the demands of her customers better. She plans to gets supplies of rice, corn, and gari (cassava flour).

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: 2 sacks of rice, 1 sack of corn, and 60 measures of gari

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Greetings from Vincent N. in Nyakabanda Sector, Nyarugenge District, Kigali (the capital city of Rwanda)! Vincent is 29 years old and still single.

Vincent operates a jewellery shop in town where he sells various sorts of jewellery such as finger rings, toe rings, necklaces, chains, earrings, bracelets, and much more. He employs 2 people in his business.

This Entrepreneur is requesting a loan worth 500,000 Rwf, which will help him to expand his business by buying various pieces of fashion jewellery. This loan will be repaid in eight months on a monthly basis.

loans.use: Expand his jewelry business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary K. is 47 years old and is divorced with five kids. Three are currently are in school and the older ones among them are married. She lives in a family house at Abofour in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Mary is going through thick and thin in struggling to take care of her family. She is supportive, determined and above all very hardworking.

Mary is a petty trader who trades in bags of maize. Her kids are very proud of her because of the enormous contribution she makes to the home. Selling maize has enabled her to rent accommodations for her family. She wants to use the loan to purchase more bags of maize to increase her inventory. She believes this loan would help her save for her children's education. She would be grateful for your assistance. Mary belongs to a village bank called ‘Asedaben’ which means Thanksgiving.

loans.use: To buy bulk supplies of maize.

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en:
Georgina A. is a married 32 year old trader with four children. She lives with her family in Abofour which is a farming community in the Ashanti region. She believes in hard work and dedication as the primary antidote to minimizing poverty, and for that reason, she is very serious about her business.

Georgina trades in cereals like maize and started her business eleven years ago in Offinso but soon realized that business was slow. Georgina then relocated to the next town, which is Abofour, and has remained in business since then. She wants to use the loan to buy larger supplies of maize to serve her customers throughout the season, especially in the face of increasing prices due to the current food crisis in the country. She believes that she can buy more bags of maize grains from the farmers and cut out the middlemen who sell to her at a high price.

Georgina belongs to a village bank called ‘Asedaben’ which means Thanksgiving.

loans.use: To buy a larger supply of maize.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy S. is a forty eight year old married woman with seven children – one boy and six girls. One of her children is learning a trade; three are currently in school while the rest are out of school and living independently. She lives together with her children and husband in Koforidua, a small community near Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. Koforidua is a business and farming community in the region. Mercy’s husband is farmer. She works to support her husband to help provide for the family.

Mercy sells vegetable cooking oil and uncooked rice in cups. She sells in a shed in the local market square. Mercy procures bags of rice and cartons of cooking oil from big grocery shops in the nearby cities, especially Kumasi, the regional capital. Mercy has managed this business for as long as twenty years. According to her, most of her customers are food vendors in her community. She wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to make more profit so she can help her children in school.

loans.use: To procure bags of rice and vegetable oil.

loans.name: Isabel

texts.es:
A sus cuarenta y cinco años, Isabel maneja un restaurante muy próspero. Ella se dedicaba a vender comida a trabajadores de una obra de construcción en el centro de la ciudad. Todos los días preparaba una cantidad de almuerzos y los llevaba a sus clientes en el mismo lugar de trabajo. Una vez que el proyecto de construcción terminó, así como los obreros, Isabel también se quedó sin trabajo. 

No obstante, le nació la idea de vender comida en su casa. Negocio que luego de mucho trabajo se convirtió en un restaurante donde cuenta con la ayuda de dos personas y con concurrencia  de numerosos clientes. Isabel se siente muy positiva frente a su negocio y quisiera abrir un local más en otro lugar más céntrico.

Paralelo a su negocio de comidas, Isabel vende eventualmente y por temporadas, zapatos, sandalias, panteones, turrones, etc.
texts.en:
At 45-years-old, Isabel manages a very successful restaurant. She used to sell food to workers from a construction site in the center of the city. Every day she would prepare a lot of lunches and would take them to her customers where they worked. After the construction project was completed, just like the workers, Isabel was left without a job. Neverthesless, she had the idea to sell food at her home. This is a business that later on, after a lot of work, she turned into a restaurant where she has the help of two people. Numerous customers frequent it. Isabel feels very positive about her business and would like to open another location in a more central place. Along with her food business, Isabel would like to sell seasonal items like shoes, sandals, Christmas candies, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To open another restaurant location and improve the exterior of her location.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace K. is a widowed 60 year old trader and mother of eight children. All of her children are now adults. She resides in the Abofour community in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Her husband died after a short battle with an illness.

Grace is a very resourceful single mother whose hard effort brings income to the family. For the past three years, Grace has supported her kids through the sale of used clothing. Selling used clothing is big business in Ghana as brand new clothes are very expensive for the economically active poor. Grace travels to a nearby city called Kumasi to purchase her stock of goods. She wants to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothing to increase her inventory. She believes this loan will help her save for her children's future and rent a store to trade.

Grace belongs to a village bank called ‘Asedaben’ which means Thanksgiving.

loans.use: To buy bales of used clothing.

loans.name: Simon

texts.fr: Originaire de Ganvié,village lacustre, Monsieur M. Simon est âgé de 40 ans,il n'a apprit aucun métier et a été initié dès son adolescence à la pêche par son feu père. Marié à M. Philomène,il a 7 enfants dont le dernier s'appelle Guillaume. Il ne vit que de la pêche ,et depuis quelques années,il  a ajouté la vente de produits de réparation de barque:peinture noire,pointes et tôles.Il sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer ces diverses activités.
texts.en:
From the lakeside village of Ganvié, Mr. Simon M., age 40, did not learn a trade, though at a young age, he was introduced to fishing by his late father. He is married to Philomène M. and has seven children; the youngest is named Guillaume. He makes a living from fishing. And a few years ago, he included the sale of boat repair materials: black paint, points, and sheet metal. He is requesting this loan to bolster these diverse activities.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For fishing (such as nets and other materials)

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy A. is a forty two year old widow that has four children – two boys and two girls. All of her children are currently in school. She lives together with her children in a family house in Koforidua, a small community near Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. Koforidua is a business and farming community in the region. Lucy works very hard to take care of the family and, most importantly, to pay the children’s school fees.

Lucy owns a small drug store in front of the family house. She sells all kinds of drugs – tablets, syrups, local concoctions, etc... Lucy purchases her drugs from big pharmacy shops in the big cities, especially Kumasi, the regional capital. Lucy has managed this business for more than twenty years and is full of experience. As a result, many town folks shop in her store all day long. She would like a loan to procure drugs in bulk to meet her clients increasing demand and make more profit.

loans.use: To procure drugs for her shop.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy N. is 45 years old and is married with six children. All her children are enrolled in a community school. Mercy lives in a farming community named Abofour, a suburb of Offinso, in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Abofour is a forest reserve area and the most popular occupation is farming. Most residents are farmers and the illiteracy rate is very high among the adults. The highest education most families can give their children is junior high school. The lack of education has been the cause of the areas highest unemployment rate in Ghana.

Mercy is a seasoned farmer and she has been farming in the area of cocoa and cereals, like maize, for more than eight years. She has managed to build a house for her family. Mercy owns larger acres of cocoa and maize but has recently been facing problems due to a disease attacking her cocoa farm. Mercy would like a loan to purchase farm inputs like cocoa chemicals, spraying machines, fertilizers and agro chemicals etc. With the loan, Mercy believes she will be able to harvest more this year and in the years ahead.

Mercy would also like to use part of her profit to support her children's education. Mercy belongs to a village bank called ‘Asedaben’.

loans.use: To buy larger farm inputs like agro chemicals, fertilizers and farm equipment.

loans.name: Julissa

texts.es:
Julissa es madre y también padre de dos pequeños niños. A los pocos años de tener a su primer hijo se separo con el padre de ese y hace unos pocos años falleció lamentablemente el padre del hijo menor. Situación que la ha llevado a trabajar en lo que ha podido para poder mantener a sus hijos.

Aunque su mama la apoya brindándole alimento y un techo donde vivir, ella debe velar por la educación de sus hijos. 

Empezó vendiendo golosinas en la puerta de su casa, pero poco a poco, gracias a su empeño, fue creciendo en sus ventas y hoy en día no solo se dedica a vender golosinas, sino también accesorios de bisutería. Mas adelante quisiera construir un local para implementar una tienda.
texts.en:
Julissa is both mother and father to two small children. A few years ago after having her first son, she separated from his father. Several years ago the father of her youngest son sadly passed away. This is a situation that has brought her to work in what she can to be able to support her sons. Although her mom helps her by offering them food and a roof under which to sleep, she needs to look out for the education of her sons. She started selling sweets at the entrance of her house, but little by little, thanks to her hard work, her sales grew. Now she not only sells sweets but also accessories. In the future, she would like to construct a location to start a store.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Marilu

texts.es:
Vendiendo especerías y condimentos para la cocina Marilú se gana la vida. Ella es madre soltera y aunque su mamá le ha ofrecido siempre apoyo, siempre ha tenido que ver los medios para poder cubrir los gastos de su hija.

Empezó trabando en el negocio de su made, vendiendo en un puesto ambulante pollos. Luego de tres años aproximadamente su hermana la anima a alquilar un puesto en el mercado más cercano a su casa. Una vez que empezaron a vender en aquel puesto su hermana se retira del negocio y ella quedo a cargo de él.

Hoy ya tiene cinco años vendiendo en el mercado, más adelante ella anhela tener un puesto propio y poder vender mayor cantidad de productos.
texts.en:
Marilú earns her living selling cooking spices and condiments. She is a single mother, and while her mother has always offered support, her main concern has always been with having the means to support her daughter. She started out working in her mother's business, selling chickens as a street vendor. After about three years, her sister encouraged her to rent a stand at the market closer to her home. Once they had started selling there, her sister left the business and Marilú took charge. She's been selling in the market for five years, and she dreams of owning a stand of her own and being able to sell more products.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more merchandise

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Afia

texts.en: Afia P. is a twenty nine year old married woman with three children– one female and two males. Two of her children are already in school while the youngest has yet to start. Afia lives with her husband and her children in a family house in Koforidua, a small community near Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. Koforidua is a business and farming community in the region. Her husband is a farmer. He cultivates plantain and cassava. Afia is a food vendor and has been in business for three years. She cooks rice and stew and sells her food from a small table top in the house she lives in. Afia says she buys the rice from the distributors in her community and surrounding towns. She is requesting a loan to procure bags of rice in bulk. Afia hopes to save enough to help her husband put up a building of their own and sponsor their children through to the university level.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize in bulk.

loans.name: Hyacinthe

texts.en:
Greetings From Hyacinthe K. in Kanombe Sector, Kicukiro District, Kigali (the capital city of Rwanda)! Hyacinthe is 28 years old, married with 3 children and 2 other dependents.

Hyacinthe started her business three years ago. Hyacinthe runs a charcoal store where she sells charcoal wholesale in her local area. She employs 4 people to help her run her business.

This entrepreneur is requesting a loan worth 500,000 Rwf. She said with this loan, she would be able to further expand her charcoal business. She will be repaying in eight months on a monthly basis.

loans.use: Expansion of her charcoal business

loans.name: Léontine

texts.fr: Née le 30/10/1975 à ZA-KPOTA d'un père cultivateur;  Léontine A. n'est jamais allée à l'école. Mariée à KIKI Bienvenu, électricien,elle a 3 enfants: Hans,Jeffry, et Claudette.  Adolescente ,elle alla en apprentissage et apprit la coiffure, voici 12 ans déjà qu'elle exerce le métier à son propre compte.Entre temps, elle associa la vente ambulante de mèches à son activité:elle dispose de deux domestiques qu'elle emploie à cela .C'est pour renforcer cette activité et la diversifier  avec la vente d'igname et autres articles.
texts.en:
Born on October 30, 1975 in ZA-KPOTA and the daughter of a farmer, Léontine A. never went to school. She is married to Bienvenu KIKI, an electrician, and has three children: Hans, Jeffry, and Claudette. When a teenager, she entered an apprenticeship and learned hairdressing. She has had her own hairdressing business for twelve years already. Meanwhile, she has included door-to-door sales of hair extensions to her business: she has two employees for this. This loan is for bolstering this business and diversifying it through the sale of yams and other goods.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: 25 tubs of yams and 2 boxes of hair extensions

loans.name: Sakina

texts.en:
Sakina M. is a 35 year old married mother of four children. At the moment, they are all in school. She sells baby clothes, pampers, powder, napkins, detergents, feeding bottles etc. by selling door to door. She balances her stock on her head and walks miles to her customers. She is requesting the loan to enable her to increase her stock and to make more income in order to provide her children with a good education. Sakina says she would be grateful for your assistance. Sakina would also like to save money to rent a store so that her burden of selling door to door would be minimized.

Sakina belongs to a village bank called ‘Yerempa Aba’ which means "We Will Not Give Up".

loans.use: To buy more supplies of baby clothes, napkins, pampers, baby oil, detergents and plastic materials.

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.es:
Cuando Maria Elena se separó de su esposo se vio en la necesidad de trabajar en lo que fuera con el fin de mantener a sus cuatro hijos y los gatos de la casa. En un principio lavó ropa a personas desconocidas y limpió en casas adineradas.

Luego de varios años y gracias a unas amigas le nació la idea de poner un negocio. Como no tenía dinero pensó en vender productos de limpieza. No disponía de mucha capital por lo que su mercadería empezó siendo mínima. Poco a poco y gracias a su esfuerzo ha podido crecer y cumplir sus propósitos.

Hoy en día maneja su puesto de venta de productos de limpieza pero en un puesto propio en el mercado de su casa. Dentro de un tiempo quisiera abrir una tienda en su propia casa.
texts.en:
When Maria Elena separated from her husband she found she needed to work to support her four children and her housecats. At first she did laundry for people she didn't know, and cleaned in well-to-do households. After a few years and thanks to some friends, she came up with the idea of going into business. Since she didn't have a lot of money she decided to sell cleaning products. She didn't have much capital, so her inventory was small at first. Little by little and by virtue of her own efforts, she has been able to grow, and achieve her goals. Nowadays she has a cleaning products stand, but it's located in the market near her house. After a while she would like to open a store in her own house.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: New merchandise

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Abena

texts.en: Abena A. is twenty five years old, is not married but has one child, a little girl. She lives with her daughter's father in a rented apartment in Koforidua, a small farming town not very far from Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana.  Abena says she works to save money and so that she can acquire her basic needs and get prepared for marriage. For the past 6 years, she has been trading in cosmetics such as creams, pomades, body lotion, and many other products. She procures her goods from big cosmetic shops in the big cities at wholesale prices. Abena sells door to door and through the local market. It is Abena’s dream to save enough money to expand her business by acquiring a store. She would like a loan to procure items in bulk so that she can maximize her profit margin.

loans.use: To procure pomades and cosmetics for sale.

loans.name: Ana María

texts.es:
Ana María es madre de cuatro hijos tres de ellos han conformado una familia propia. Lamentablemente su esposo falleció hace siete años, desde entonces se encarga de mantener los gastos de la casa por su cuenta.

En un inicio Ana Maria se dedicaba a tejer chompas y confeccionar joyas. Junto con un grupo de amigas trabajaban para una empresa, la cual se encargaba de exportar. Alrededor de diez años después, obtuvo un cargo importante en el comedor popular de su localidad, cargo que le impidió continuar con su trabajo en la empresa.

Una vez que abandono el cargo de la presidencia en el comedor se le ocurrió vender ropa por pedido y hace poco a implementado su negocio con la venta de cervezas. Gracias a su trabajo no solo cubre os gastos dela casa sino también la educación de su ultimo hijo.
texts.en:
Ana María is the mother of four children. Three of them have now formed their own families. Unfortunately, her husband died seven years ago. Since then she has been responsible for providing for her family.

At first, Ana Maria made a living knitting sweaters and making jewelry. She worked with a group of friends for a company that exported their products. About ten years after, she was given an important job at a popular restaurant in her neighborhood. She had to quit her job working for the company.

Once she left her job as the president of the restaurant, it occurred to her to start selling clothing and a little while ago she also started to sell beer. Thanks to her new activities she is not only able to cover all the costs of her home, she is also able to pay for the education of her youngest child.

(Translated by Alexis of San Roque High School)

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The Purchase of Merchandise

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Clarisse

texts.en:
Greetings from Clarisse I. in Gatsata Sector, Gasabo District, Kigali (capital of Rwanda)! Clarisse is 22 and the mother of 1 child. She has one orphan to raise as well.

She started her business two years ago. She has a spare parts shop with capital of 1,000,000 RWF at Gatsata Sector where she has many customers. She wants to increase her working capital and she now understands how good it is to work with microinance like Vision Finance Company s.a. She is requesting a loan of 500,000 Rwf with a loan period of 8 months.

loans.use: Increase her working capital

loans.name: Hanna

texts.en: Hanna A. is a forty year old married woman with three children, two girls and a boy. One of the children is in junior high school and the other two are in elementary school. She lives with the family in Koforidua, a small town not very far from Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. It is entirely a farming and commercial town. Hanna works to support her husband who makes his living as a farmer. He cultivates cocoa and some foodstuffs. Hanna trades in banana. Most of the women in the community trade in banana and other fruits. She buys unripe banana from farmers in the nearby villages, stores them to ripen and then sells them to retailers in her community in the local market. She at times sells by the roadside with roasted groundnut. Hanna has had this business for three years. It has been her dream to save enough money to support her husband take care of the family. She wants a loan to procure banana in bulk so she can maximize her profit margin.

loans.use: To procure bananas in bulk.

loans.name: Sara Teodora

texts.es:
Hace dos años que Sara vende cerveza y chicha junto con su esposo. En un inicio vendía en su casa pero ahora el negocio de ha trasladado al local donde el esposo trabaja como herrero. Por ahora ella solo se dedica a vender los fines de semana pues se encuentra delicada de salud y próxima a una operación. 

Anteriormente, ofrecía el servicio de limpieza en una tienda de muebles; sin embargo, una vez que estuvo a cargo de su nieta tuvo que abandonar el trabajo, es por eso que se animó a abrir su negocio en casa. Las ganancias la ayudan a colaborar con los gasto de su nieta y también de su casa.
texts.en:
Sara has been selling beer and a beverage called “chicha” for the past two years with her husbands. In the beginning she use to sell it out of her house, now the business has moved to her husband's place of employment where he works as a blacksmith. For now she only sells on the weekends since she is experiencing health problems and she is getting ready to have an operation.

Before she use to offer cleaning services at a furniture store; however, once she was left in charge of her granddaughter and she had to leave her job. That’s why she finally deiced to start her own business at home. Her earnings allow her to contribute to providing for her granddaughter and also to the costs of her household.

Translated by Sonia of San Roque High School

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Merchandise

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Angelique

texts.en:
Greetings from Angelique M. in Gatsata Sector, Gasabo District, Kigali (capital of Rwanda)! Angelique is 31 years old and the mother of 2 kids. She has no orphans to raise.

She started her business two years ago. She has a spare parts store with capital of 1,100,000 RWF at Gatsata Sector where she has many customers. She wants to increase her working capital.

This entrepreneur is requesting a loan worth 500,000 Rwf which will be repaid in eight months on a monthly basis

loans.use: Increase her working capital

loans.name: Eugenie

texts.fr: Dame M. Eugenie a 19 ans et elle est nee a Savalou d'un père cultivateur et d'une mère revendeuse .Elle fréquenta jusqu'en classe de 3ème où elle eut son Brevet d'Etude de Premier Cycle(BEPC).Puis elle débrancha pour apprendre l'hôtellerie-restauration et eut son diplôme il y a juste 1 an. Par manque de moyens financiers , elle s'est lancée dans la vente de pagnes pour plus tard créer son propre maquis car elle veut travailler à son propre compte. Actuellement,elle a épuisé son stock de pagnes et compte se réapprovisionner par ce  premier crédit en vue d'accroître son étalage .
texts.en:
Ms. Eugenie M. is 19 years old, and she was born in Savalou. Her father was a farmer and her mother, a retailer. She attended school through the 9th grade and earned her BEPC (middle school diploma). Then she dropped out to learn the hotel-restaurant business and got her certificate just a year ago. Due to a lack of financial means, she got started in the sale of pagnes (colorful West African cloth), so as to establish her own eatery eventually, because she wants to work and be on her own. Presently, she has exhausted her inventory of pagnes and plans to resupply herself through this loan in order to expand her display of goods.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: 15 lengths of Wax Hollandais brand cloth

loans.name: Guadalupe Del Carmen

texts.es:
Guadalupe recibe préstamos de EDAPROSPO desde hace 3 años. Antes para mantener su negocio, una tienda de abarrotes, gaseosas y cervezas, sacaba préstamos de su banco, pero le parecieron mejores las condiciones de los préstamos de EDAPROSPO.

Antes de tener su propia tienda Guadalupe alquilaba un stand en el mercado. Trabajó allí durante cuatro años, y su esposo todavía se ocupa de este negocio.
Sus ganancias en parte las ahorra para el futuro en un banco, y lo demás lo usa para cubrir los gastos de la educación de sus hijos menores, un chico de trece años y una niña de cuatro.

A sus cuarenta años Guadalupe ahorra rigurosamente para construir un futuro más seguro por sus hijas, y con tiempo ampliar su bodega, hasta tener una fotocopiadora para proveer un servicio más en su tienda.
texts.en:
Guadalupe has received loans from EDAPROSO for the past three year. She got a loan from her bank so that she could maintain her business, a store for groceries, soft drinks & beer. She used to get loans from her bank until she found out that the loan terms with EDAPROSO were much better.

Before having her own business, Guadalupe used to lease a stand at a market. She worked there for four years and her husband is still in charge of the business. She puts part of her earnings aside in a bank account, and she uses the rest to cover the costs of the education of her youngest children, a son who is three years old, and a daughter who is four years old.

At her forty years of age, Guadalupe works hard to make money to build a stronger and more secure future for her children, and also to make her business grow She would even like to have a photocopier to provide yet another service at her store.

(Translated by Sonia of San Roque High School)

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase Food Items To Sell At Store

loans.name: Aditcha

texts.fr: Dame A. Aditcha,âgée de 45 ans ,est revendeuse de condiments,liqueurs et divers autres articles (piles, conserves, huile rouge et autres).Elle n'a jamais été à l'école  et réside dans un quartier lacustre ,périphérique de Cotonou. Elle a commencé à faire le petit commerce depuis qu'elle est adolescente. Elle a été initiée par sa défunte tutrice. Dame A. Aditcha a sollicité ce 2è prêt pour renforcer son activité et s'approvisionner surtout en liqueurs et sucreries dont les stocks sont totalement épuisés.Originaire de Ganvié, elle est mariée et n'a pas eu la chance d'avoir des enfants.
texts.en:
Ms. Aditcha A., age 45, is a retailer of condiments, liqueurs, and various other goods (batteries, canned foods, red palm oil, and more). She never attended school and resides in a lakeside district on the edge of Cotonou. She started in small-scale commerce as a teenager, being introduced to it by her deceased tutor.

Ms. A. is requesting this second loan to bolster her business and to stock up, especially with liqueurs and soft drinks, which are totally depleted from her inventory. She is from Ganvié, married, and without children, since she has not had the chance.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: 2 boxes of liqueurs and 3 cases of soft drinks

loans.name: Juliette

texts.fr: Née le 30 juillet 1982 à Savalou dont Juliette G. est originaire dans le département des collines au centre du Bénin. Dame G. eut la chance d'être instruite. Elle abandonna les classes  en 4ème et apprit la couture.Après son diplôme de fin d'apprentissage,elle vint à Cotonou où elle a suivi une formation en informatique pour être opératrice de saisie.Après un an d'exercice du métier, elle changea d'activité et se lança dans le commerce de produits cosmétiques.A cela, elle a associé aussi la vente de boissons: bières et sucreries.Par ce deuxième crédit,elle désire non seulement renforcer son stock de mèches en s'approvisionnant en de nouvelles gammes mais aussi s'approvisionner en liqueurs de tous genres.
texts.en:
Born on July 30, 1982 in Savalo, which is where she is from, in Collines County in central Bénin, Ms. Juliette G. had the opportunity to attend school. She abandoned it in the 8th grade and then learned dressmaking. After earning her apprenticeship certificate, she went to Cotonou, where she got training in computers in order to be a data processor. After a year in this profession, she switched and got started doing commerce in cosmetics. To this, she added the sale of beverages: beer and soft drinks. With this second loan, she would like not only to boost her inventory of hair extensions with a supply of new types but to get supplies of all kinds of liqueurs.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: 12 dozen hair extensions, 3 dozen cosmetic products, 3 boxes of liqueurs

loans.name: Thacienne

texts.en:
Muraho (Hellooo!) from Thacienne M. in Gatsata Sector, Gasabo District, Kigali (capital of Rwanda). Thacienne is 31, the mother of 4 kids. She has no orphans to raise.

She started her business one year and six months ago. She has a spare part shop with capital of 1,100,000 RWF at Gatsata Sector where she has many customers. She wants to increase her working capital.

This entrepreneur is requesting a loan worth 500,000 Rwf which will be repaid over eight months. Thacienne believes that this loan will help her to expand her spare parts shop and that her profit will increase.

loans.use: Increase her working capital

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en:
Greetings from Jacqueline U. in Gatsata Sector, Gasabo District, Kigali (capital of Rwanda)! Jacqueline is 44 and the mother of 4 kids. She has no orphans to raise.

She started her business eight months ago. Jacqueline has a spare parts business. She sells different types of car spare parts with capital of 1,100,000 RWF at Gatsata Sector where she has many customers.

This Entrepreneur is requesting a loan worth 500,000 Rwf which will help her to expand her business. She also wants to increase her working capital. This loan will be repaid over eight months.

loans.use: Expand her Business

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Greetings from Betty M. in Nyamirambo Sector, Nyarugenge District, Kigali (the capital city of Rwanda)! Betty is 30 years old, married with one child.

She started her business 9 years ago. This entrepreneur operates a shop where she sells different kinds of clothes. Betty employs one person to help her to run this business; she earns about 150,000 Rwf in monthly income.

Betty is requesting a loan worth 500,000Rwf, which will help her to expand her business. This loan will be repaid in 8 months on monthly basis. Betty believes that once she gets this loan her profit will increase.

loans.use: Expand her clothing business

loans.name: Pasos Firme Group

texts.en:
“Pasos Firme” is a group of five, all but one illiterate, entrepreneurs seeking additional loan funds from Esperanza International. The group’s past loans have been successfully repaid, and the group hopes to utilize an additional loan for further business expansion. Luisa is the coordinator for this group in El Seybo.

Luisa, mother of a ten-year-old child, operates three notably different entrepreneurial sales. Luisa sells vegetables, cellular phone recharge cards, and gas for stove-top cooking and lamps. Recently, Luisa’s husband has fallen ill, leaving Luisa to care for her ill husband and child, and continue to work for prosperity within her business. However, Luisa is dedicated and dreams of one day owning her own home.

Other members of Luisa’s bank run similar entrepreneurial operations including selling chicken, clothing, and undergarment sales. The bank as a whole is committed to successful completion of this additional micro-finance loan and past performance demonstrates competence and commitment.

On behalf of Esperanza and this group of business entrepreneurs, we would like to thank you for your support!

loans.use: Purchase additional materials for re-sale

loans.name: Pasos Firme Group

texts.en:
Ana operates a variety store. In her store she is able to offer a wide variety of products including meats, vegetables, coffee, sugar, stove-top gas for cooking, and men’s and women’s clothing. Aided by Esperanza International, Ana has been able purchase materials in greater bulk to gain savings advantages and offer wider product variety to her customers. Ana has encountered some setbacks over the life of her business, including the death of loved ones, but her ambition remains to own her own home and to encourage the prosperity of her children (ages: 32, 30, 27, 24, 22, 20).

Ana is not alone in her quest to succeed through entrepreneurial activities. Ana is a member of the micro-finance bank “Pasos Firme”. Along with four other women, Ana is seeking additional loan funds from Esperanza to encourage growth in her business. Other member’s of Ana’s micro-finance bank run similar entrepreneurial ventures including selling fried food and ice cream, and used clothing sales.

On behalf of Esperanza and this group of business entrepreneurs, we would like to thank you for your support!

loans.use: Purchase additional needed inventory for variety store

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en:
This is Zainab M.. Zainab was born in Sanda, about eighteen miles from Makeni. She is thirty-eight years of age. She is married to a businessman. They have five children together, all of whom are still pupils. Zainab sells slippers and plastic sandals. She has been in this business for thirteen years now. Zainab is requesting a loan of Le 3,000,000. This will be her very first loan from SMT as an individual client.

With this loan, Zainab will increase her business by buying more slippers to add to her current stock. She will use the loan to buy ten dozen slippers, seven dozen foam slippers, and one carton of “madam” shoes. She buys the slippers and shoes in Freetown, Sierra Leone’s capital city, a 372-mile round trip from Makeni. A dozen slippers costs her Le 120,000; a dozen foam slippers costs Le 95,000, and a dozen madam shoes costs Le 120,000 in Freetown.

So far, business is going fine for Zainab. She faces no major challenges in her business. Her business is her only source of income. She loves her business and enjoys doing it. With this loan she receives from SMT, Zainab is expecting a vast improvement in her business and also an incremental increase in the amount of profit she makes. An increase in profit means paying school fees for children, feeding the family better, and offering support to members of her extended family.

loans.use: To buy ten dozen slippers, seven dozen foam slippers, and one carton of “madam” shoes

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
This is Fatmata J., age forty. Fatmata was born in Makeni, in northern Sierra Leone. She is married to a businessman and the two have two children. One is in secondary school and the other has dropped out of school and is now training to become a motor mechanic. Fatmata sells cloth: cottons and “Laise” cottons. She has been in business for over twenty years now. She began the business when she was a little child with her mum. This will be her very first loan from SMT. She is requesting a loan of Le 3,000,000 to help her strengthen her business.

With this loan, Fatmata will expand her business by buying two bales of cottons to add to her current stock. She will need additional money from her capital to enable her to buy the two bales. A bale of cotton in Freetown costs Le 1,500,000 and a bale of Laise cotton costs Le 1,700,000. The fare to Freetown is Le 24,000 round trip. There is a Le 1000 delivery charge for each bale transported with her from Freetown.

Business is going fine for Fatmata. The only challenge she has been facing is that of low capital, but with the loan she now receives from SMT, that challenge has been overcome. With this loan she receives from SMT, Fatmata is expecting a vast improvement in her business and an incremental increase in the amount of profit she makes. The increase in profit will make her feel good.

loans.use: Buy one bale of cotton and one bale of laise cotton

loans.name: Pasos Firme Group

texts.en:
Avelia operates two significantly differently entrepreneurial activities. Avelia sells both sweets and gasoline. Aided by Esperanza International, Avelia has been able to purchase additional materials, including the needed ingredient to produce her sweets and additional levels of gasoline, to increase the level of sales for both entrepreneurial activities and gain a greater return. Thus far, throughout the life of her business, Avelia has encountered some setbacks including the deaths of loved ones, but her ambition remains to own her own “colmado”, or small store one day, and encourage the growth and education of her children (ages: 18, 15, 11, 9).

Avelia is not alone in her quest to succeed through entrepreneurial activities. Avelia is a member of the micro-finance bank “Pasos Firme”. All the members of the bank are illiterate. Along with the four other women, Avelia is seeking additional loan funds from Esperanza to encourage growth in her business. Other members of Avelia’s microfinance bank run similar entrepreneurial ventures including selling peanut butter and assorted food sales.

On behalf of Esperanza and this group of business entrepreneurs, we would like to thank you for your support!

loans.use: Purchase additional needed materials for sweets and additional gasoline for re-sale

loans.name: Yao

texts.fr: Ce monsieur célibataire habite le quartier de kégué, il fait le commerce de friperie derrière le marché d’assiyéyé où il s’approvisionne, il fait ce commerce depuis 2005, le commerce de friperie est une activité qui marche bien à lomé. Il sollicite son premier crédit de wages pour acheter 05 balles de chemises. Il n’est pas marié mais avec ce qu’il gagne il aide les autres membres de sa famille.
texts.en:
This unmarried gentleman lives in the Kégué district. He does commerce in used clothing behind the Assiyéyé marketplace, where he gets his inventory. Since 2005, this has been his work, which is a good business in Lomé. He is requesting his first WAGES loan to buy five bales of shirts. He is not married, but with what he earns, he helps the other members of his family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bales of shirts

loans.name: Yentiyié

texts.fr: K. Yentiyié est un jeune homme célibataire qui travaille très dur pour gagner sa vie, il fait comme activité génératrice de revenu la vente de pièces détachées de motos ou véhicules, il réside dans le quartier de N’kafu il n’a jamais obtenu de crédit de chez  wages et sollicite son premier crédit d’un montant de 300.000F  pour agrandir son stock avec des pièces à détachées. Il s’approvisionne au Ghana et souvent dans le marché du port. Il aide beaucoup ses frères et sœurs.
texts.en:
Yentiyié K. is a young unmarried man who works very had to earn a living selling spare parts for motorbikes and vehicles. He resides in the N’kafu district and has never been the recipient of a WAGES loan. He is requesting his first loan in the amount of 300,000 francs to expand his inventory of spare parts. He stocks up in Ghana and often at the marketplace at the port. He assists his brother and sisters a lot.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Rosa Elvira

texts.es:
Rosa, con sus treinta y nueve años, tiene una historia de trabajos bastante variada. En su juventud trabajó durante cinco años de empleada en una tienda de ropa intima. Sin embargo tuve que dejar este trabajo cuando estaba embarazada de su segunda hija, por que tuvo dos amenazas de aborto.

Volvió a trabajar después de un tiempo por ayudar a su esposo, que era visitador medico, y que en este tiempo no lograba dar a su familia el nivel de vida deseado con su solo empleo. Ahora ya desde hace cuatro años tiene un contrato fijo en un laboratorio.

Rosa volvió a trabajar vendiendo anticuchos en las calles, justo fuera de su casa, durante cuatro años. Quería trabajar en algo que le dejara estar cerca de sus dos hijos menores. Hace tres años empezó a recibir préstamos de EDAPROSPO, y así pude empezar otro negocio que le interesaba más: la venta de cosméticos.

Contribuye a los gastos del hogar pagando los servicios y cubriendo los consumos de su niños, lo que sobra lo reinvierte en su negocio.

Está conversando con una amiga para juntarse y abrir un salón de belleza en el futuro próximo.
texts.en:
In her 39 years, Rosa has had a wide variety of jobs. In her youth she worked for 5 years as an employee in and underwear shop. However, she had to leave this job when she was pregnant with her second daughter because she had two threats of miscaraige.

She returned to work to help her husband, then working as a visiting doctor, who could not support the family alone. Now, four years later, Rasa's husband has a solid job at a labratory.

Rosa resumed work selling snack foods on the street right in front of her house so that she could be close to her children. She wanted to work in something that would not make her leave her two youngest children alone. Three years ago she began to receive loans from EDAPROSPO, so she could start a business that she enjoyed more, selling cosmetics.

Rosa contributes to the family, helping pay for services and food. She invests any left over money in her business. Rosa hope to start a beauty salon with her friend in the near future.

(Translated by Ally of San Roque School)

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: New Merchandise (Cosmetics)

loans.name: Florencia Teofila

texts.es:
Florencia empezó con su tienda de abarrotes y gaseosas desde hace un año y medio año. El local que alquila es parte de la casa de su madre en Comas; tuvo que organizarse así por que donde vive ella su negocio no es rentable. A parte de la tienda, Florencia también vende cosméticos.

Empezó sacando préstamos de otro banco, pero hace un mes se animó a juntarse a las alcancías comunales de EDAPROSPO gracias a su hermana que le contó de las posibilidades de ahorros que vienen con los préstamos. 
Mientras que su esposo, maestro de construcción con contrato de trabajo, se encarga de pagar por la luz, la electricidad y la comida, a sus treinta y nueve años Florencia es responsable de cubrir los demás gastos, el gas, útiles que falten de la casa, y los consumos de sus dos hijos de quince y diez años.

En el futuro le gustaría agrandar su tienda, amoblarla, y ponerle algo de seguridad, puesto que ha sufrido un robo hace poco y quiere evitar estar en riesgo.
texts.en:
Florencia began her soft drink and general store a-year-and-a-half ago. The business space that she is renting is a part of her mother’s house in Comas. She had to set up her store this way because the business is not lucrative where she lives. Aside from running the store, she also sells cosmetics.

She started out with loans from the bank, but one month ago, she made up her mind to join the community bank of EDAPROSPO thanks to her sister, who told her about the chances of savings that come with the loans. While her husband, a construction worker with a contract, pays for the electricity and the food bills, 33-year-old Florencia is responsible for covering the rest of the expenses, such as the gas bill, other utilities, and anything that their children, ages 15 and 10, may need.

In the future, she would like to expand her general store, furnish it, and install security equipment because she was recently robbed and would like to avoid being at risk.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase soft drinks and other beverages

loans.name: Mawuena

texts.fr: A. Mawuna  est une femme qui habite le quartier d’adidogomé, elle n’est pas mariée mais elle a quatre enfants à sa charge  elle fait la restauration dans le quartier d’agoè assiyéyé, elle le fait cette activité depuis 1982. Elle n’a jamais obtenu de crédit de wages et elle sollicite son premier crédit de wages d’un montant de 300000 pour acheter 04 sacs de maïs et des condiments pour son activité de restauration
texts.en:
Mawuna A. is a woman who lives in the Adidogomé neighborhood. She's unmarried but has four children to support. She's been a caterer in the Agoè Assiyéyé neighborhood since 1982. She's never got a loan before from Wages, and she's now seeking her first one for an amount of XOF 300'000 (ca US$ 600) to buy 4 sacks of corn, as well as condiments, for her catering business.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 4 sacks of corn and condiments

loans.name: Kudzo

texts.fr: B. Koudjo est un monsieur qui habite le quartier  de tokoin wuiti, il est un revendeur de friperie et ce depuis 2000, il s’approvisionne au marché d’assiyéyé à Lomé, il n’a jamais obtenu de crédit de chez wages et sollicite son premier crédit pour  acheter 05 balles de chemises, 02 balles de pantalons et des chaussures.Il est un célibataire sans enfants
texts.en:
Mr. Koudjo B. lives in the Tokoin Wuiti neighborhood, and has been reselling used clothing since 2000. He gets his supplies at the Assiyéyé market in Lomé. He never got a loan from Wages before, and is now seeking his first one to buy 5 bales of shirts, 2 bales of trousers, and shoes. He's single and without children.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 5 bales of shirts, 2 bales of trousers, and shoes

loans.name: Charito

texts.es:
A sus treinta y nueve años, Charito, ha trabajado en el encuadernado y empastado de libros toda su vida. A los dieciocho años empezó trabajando en imprenta. Sin embargo, recién empezó a trabajar independientemente: hace dos años. 

Trabaja al por mayor para empresas, que la proveen con todo el material que necesita para la tarea, y ella hace el empastado, alzado y gomado de los libros. Solo necesita invertir en unas esponjas, trapos y rodillos, así que cuando empezó a recibir préstamos de EDAPROSPO pudo usarlos para cubrir gastos grandes de su casa, alcanzando reembolsar los préstamos con las ganancias de su trabajo.

Todo su trabajo es manual, así que normalmente trabaja sola, cuando recibe pedidos grandes necesita requiere la ayuda de dos o más personas.

Charito es separada, pero su esposo ayuda con los gastos de sus dos hijos menores, así que su deseo por el futuro solo es de seguir en su trabajo.
texts.en:
At 22, Charito has been working in the bookbinding business her whole life. She started working at a printing works when she was 18. However, she started working independently only two years ago.

She binds books in bulk for companies, which provide her with all the materials she needs for the task. She just needs to invest in sponges, cloths and rollers, so when she started receiving loans from EDAPROSPO, she was able to use them to cover the household expenses, managing to repay the loans with the profits earned from her job.

All her work is done manually, so she normally works alone. However, when she receives big orders, she sometimes needs help from two or more people.

Charito is separated, but her husband helps her support their two young children. Her wish for the future is to keep her job.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: New work tools

loans.name: Luis Principe

texts.es:
Para mantener a sus dos hijos menores Luis se dedica a dos negocios. Cuando hay contratos para proyectos de edificación el es maestro de construcción. Se dedica a este trabajo desde hace cuatro años. El resto del tiempo tiene un puesto en el mercado, donde vende DVD’s y CD’s. Empezó este negocio un año antes de lo de construcción. En un futuro le gustaría tener una tienda propia, por que tendría trabajo estable y podría trabajar todos los días

Luis tiene tres hijos, el menor solo tiene 3 años, pero como esta separado con su esposa el niño más joven vive con ella, mientras que los otros dos viven con el. Por ahora sus ganancias le alcanza justo para cubrir los gastos de la críanza de los niños.
texts.en:
Luis works two jobs in order to support his two young children. When there are construction projects available, Luis works as a construction worker. When there are no projects, Luis sells DVDs and CDs at the market. In the future Luis would like to own his own store because he would have a stable job and be able to work everyday.

Luis has three children. The youngest is 3 years old. He is separated from his wife and his youngest child lives with her, while the other two live with him. For now, his earnings barely allow him to provide for his children.

(Translated by Elliot of San Roque High School)

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase more tapes and CDs to sell

loans.name: Rene

texts.es:
