She is asking for a loan of Php 15,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy farm inputs. Part of the loan will also be used to buy additional merchandise for her store. She wants her business to grow and the loan will help a lot for her business expansion.

CEVI helps Evelyn grow her business. With CEVI credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage, more and more people succeed in their business.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs and merchandise for store

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria T., now 64 years old, is a pig grower and a store owner. She sells her farm produce in her store. She earns her living from farming as well from selling various goods at her farm. Four of her 8 children are married while the remaining four live with them. They are a typical Filipino family. Sons and daughters live with their parents until they get married.

In 2006, Maria started selling her rice in her store. People come to her to buy rice and other goods. She is happy about how her business is growing because it helps her a lot to cover the needs of her children.

She wants to expand into other businesses. She is asking for a loan of Php 15,000 to grow her business more for her family. She believes that with her loan, she could earn more profit from her businesses.

CEVI helps Maria sustain her business. Now, she can take advantage of credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage.

loans.use: Purchase of groceries and feed for pigs

loans.name: Khair

texts.en:
Khair M., son of Nazar M., is still young: 19 years old, he is a metal worker and he has six years' experience at this work. He lives in the first district, Nangrahar province, Jalalabad city. He is a very hard worker because he is the only one to support his whole household. He is not educated because he is the oldest son and he has had a lot of financial problems.

Khair has two brothers and one sister. His brothers are 7 and 5 years old and his little sister just 3 years old. They live in a small rented house. His father works in poultry but his salary of 5,000(AF) (100$) it is not enough for the family. Therefore, Khair is working hard and he needs 50,000(AF) loan (1075$) so he can buy some steel or other things he needs to further his business. So he is contacting Kiva lenders and requesting an individual loan of 50,000 (AF). In his shop he makes doors, windows, chairs, tables, and other things. He wants to help his family to make a better life. He is happy with this loan process and he says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: buy what is necessary for his metal shop to progress well

loans.name: Alice's Group

texts.en: Alice K. is the chairperson of Samuka group in Lugazi. She is 39 years of age and married with 4 children. Her retail shop is located right at her home and she is lucky that she does not have to spend money on rent. In her shop she sells cereals, bread, sugar, tea leaves, salt, soap, flour and many more items. This being the rainy season and the time for going back to school, cereals and stationery are selling like hot cakes. She needs a loan to be able to buy a sack of beans, maize, books, pens, and pencils for her shop.

loans.use: Products for her retail shop such as a sack of beans, maize, books, pens, and pencils

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina has been a bread seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 7 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $80. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more bread for her business. She is hopping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, improve her home, and pay the school fees of their children.

Amina is 46 years old, married, and has 3 children, ages 12, 9, and 6. She also cares for 4 additional dependents.

loans.use: To buy more bread in order to expand her business

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
Salma has been a khanga (fabric) and bread seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 6 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $90. Every day she works at her business for 14 hours. She is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more khanga and cosmetics items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business in order to save money and pay the school fees of her children.

Salma is 40 years old, divorced, and has 3 children, aged between 16 and 10.

loans.use: To buy more khanga and cosmetics items for her business

loans.name: Mwajuma

texts.en:
Mwajuma has owned a small charcoal store and has been a coconuts seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 20 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $80. Every day she works at her business for 14 hours. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal and coconuts for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business in order to improve her home and pay the school fees of her children.

Mwajuma is 44 years old, married, and has 5 children, ages 27, 24, 16, 12, and 6.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and coconuts in order to expand her business

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema has owned a small charcoal store and has been a juice and clothes seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 1 year. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $40. Every day she works at her business. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal, juice, and clothes for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business in order to save money and pay the school fees of her children.

Rehema is 27 years old, married, and has 3 children, ages 11, 7, and 2.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal, juice, and clothes for her business

loans.name: Wache Waseme Group

texts.en:
Rukia has been a food seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 4 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $65. Every day she works at her business for 14 hours. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food materials for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business in order to save money and pay the school fees of her children.

Rukia is 31 years old, married, and has 4 children, ages 17, 16, 11, and 8. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Fatma S., Sabah B., Mahaji Z., and Fatma R.. Each woman also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more food materials for her business

loans.name: Juhudi Iwepo Group

texts.en:
Sakina has been a clothing, soup, and perfume seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 13 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $190. Every day she works at her business for 16 hours. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes and perfumes for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, improve her home, and save money.

Sakina is 27 years old, married, and has one child, age 3. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Siti. Siti also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and perfumes for her business

loans.name: Hidaya

texts.en:
Hidaya has been a snack seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 6 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $80. Every day she works at her business for 14 hours. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more snack materials for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, save money, and pay the school fees of her children.

Hidaya is 42 years old, is married, and has one child, age 15.

loans.use: To buy more snack materials for her business

loans.name: Djafarou Djamila

texts.fr:
Cette dame habite le quartier de agoè atsanvé et a pour activité la vente de tissus et de chemises, elle exerce ce commerce depuis 2003, la demande a un peu augmenté ces temps ci et c’est pour y satisfaire qu’elle sollicite de wages son premier prêt d’un montant de 300000F pour se réapprovisionner avec des tissus et des pagnes, certaines personnes  de sa clientèle sont des couturières.
Elle est mariée et mère de un enfant.
texts.en:
This lady lives in the Agoè Atsanvé district and sells cloth and loose dresses. She has been in this business since 2003. Demand for her products has gone up a bit lately and it is to satisfy that demand that she has requested her first ever loan from WAGES in the amount of 300,000 F to stock up on cloth and lengths of African print fabric. Certain of her customers are seamstresses.

She is married and the mother of one child.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of cloth and African print fabric

loans.name: Maendeleo Group

texts.en:
Hana has been a bread seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 7 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $80. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more bread for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, improve her home, and pay the school fees of her children.

Hana is 38 years old, is divorced, and has 4 children. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Jabu, who also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more bread for her business

loans.name: Mshikamo Group

texts.en:
Madina has been a snack seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 1 year. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $65. Every day she works at her business for 14 hours. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more snacks for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to improve her home and to save money.

Madina is 30 years old, is divorced, and has 2 children, ages 9 and 6. She also cares for 3 additional dependents. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Mosi, who also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more snacks for her business

loans.name: Abdul

texts.en: Abdul M. is a Tanzanian businessman. He runs a business of transporting passengers from one point to another point in Dar es Salaam. He has a minibus, and has been in business for four years. He also runs a stationery shop at Kariakoo in Dar es Salaam. He managed to build a house from the business income. He needs a loan to top up the businesses.

loans.use: To boost his business.

loans.name: Tusaidiane Group

texts.en:
Tatu has owned a small store selling charcoal and firewood in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 1 year. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $80. Every day she works at her business for 16 hours. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy charcoal and firewood for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to save money and pay the school fees of her children.

Tatu is 43 years old, is married, and has 3 children, ages 25, 15, and 8. She also cares for one additional dependent. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Fatma and Khadija. Each woman also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood for her business

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica S., 44, the mother of two girls and three boys, four in school and one not yet of school age, lives with the family in Koforidua, a small farming and commercial town close to Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. Her husband works with the transport union in her community.

Monica trades in bananas, purchasing them from farmers in the nearby villages, ripening and then selling them to retailers in her community in the local market. She also at times sells roasted groundnuts by the roadside. Monica has been in business for over 15 years, and it has been her dream to save enough money to support her husband in caring for the family. She therefore is requesting a loan to procure bananas in bulk in order to maximize her profit margin, hoping to thereby sponsor her children’s ongoing education.

loans.use: To procure bananas in bulk.

loans.name: Habiba

texts.en:
Habiba has been a firewood and juice seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 5 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $250. Every day she works at her business for 14 hours. She is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more firewood and juice materials for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to pay the school fees of her children and save money.

Habiba is 40 years old, is married, and has 6 children. .

loans.use: To buy more firewood and juice materials for her business

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Thirty-four-year-old Abena B. is the mother of one girl and two boys, two in school and one yet too young to attend. She lives with the family in a rented apartment in Koforidua, a farming and commercial town not far from Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana.

Trading in bananas and oranges for the past eight years, Abena works very hard to support her husband in taking care of the family. She buys bags of oranges and unripe bananas from farmers in the nearby villages, stores the bananas to ripen and then sells to retailers in the local market. It has been her dreams to save enough money to support her children in school, so she is requesting a loan to procure bananas and oranges in bulk in order to increase her profit margin.

loans.use: To procure bananas and oranges in bulk.

loans.name: Mwachum

texts.en:
Mwachum has owned a nursery school in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 5 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $250. She works at her business for 14 hours every day. 

Mwachum is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more supplies for her business. She hopes that this loan will increase her profit so that she will be able to pay school fees for her children and save some money.  

Mwachum is 40 years old, married, and has two children aged 24 and 14.

loans.use: To buy more school materials to improve her business

loans.name: Stara

texts.en:
Stara has owned a small cosmetics shop in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 4 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $250. She works at her business for 16 hours every day. 

Stara is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more cosmetics items for her business. She hopes that with this loan she can increase her profit and grow her business, save money and pay school fees for her children.  

Stara is 42 years old, widowed, and has two children aged 18 and 7.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics items for her business.

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en:
Yaa N., 45, is married and has eight children - two girls and six boys - three in senior high school and the rest in junior high and elementary school. She lives with the family in a rented apartment in Koforidua, a small farming and commercial town not far from Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana.

For the past eight years, Yaa has worked very hard trading in bananas and oranges to help her husband take care of the family. Buying bags of oranges and unripe bananas from farmers in the nearby villages, she ripens and then sells the produce to retailers in the local market. Since it has long been her dream to save enough money to support her children in school, she is requesting a loan to procure bananas and oranges in bulk in order to increase her profit margin.

loans.use: To procure bananas and oranges in bulk.

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Thirty-year-old Regina O. is the mother of five children, two boys and three girls, one of whom has not yet begun school. She lives with the family in Koforidua, a small farming and commercial town not far from Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. Her husband owns a provisions shop.

Most of the women in the community deal in bananas and other fruits, as does Regina, who buys bananas from the nearby villages, stores them for ripening, and then sells them to retailers in the local market as well as other nearby venues.

Regina has been in business for ten years, and it is her dream to save enough money to support her husband in taking care of the family. She is therefore requesting a loan to procure bananas in bulk so as to maximize her profit margin.

loans.use: To procure bananas in bulk.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina has owned a small shop in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for many years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $125. She works at her business for 16 hours every day. 

Amina is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more merchandise for her business. She hopes that this loan will help her increase her profit so that she will be able to pay school fees for her children and save money.  

Amina is 46 years old, married, and has five children aged 30,28,26,24 and 22.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise (machines and TVs) for her business.

loans.name: Nyongo

texts.en:
Nyongo has sold bread in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 7 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $80. She works at her business for 12 hours every day. 

Nyongo is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more bread, oil and soap. She hopes that this loan will help her increase her profit so that she will be able to grow her business, improve her home and pay school fees for her children.  

Nyongo is 48 years old, divorced, and has seven children aged 30, 20, 18, 16, 14, 12 and 10.

loans.use: To buy more materials (oil and soap) for her business.

loans.name: Latifa

texts.en:
Latifa B., 35, is the mother of seven children – one female and six males - four of whom are in junior high and primary school, while the rest are currently working. Latifa lives with her husband, a farmer who cultivates palm nuts, oranges and maize, and some of the children in a rented apartment in Koforidua, a small business and farming community near Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana.

Latifa has traded in maize for the past seven years, purchasing it from farmers in her community and the surrounding towns. She sometimes procures smoked fish as well. Latifa is now requesting a loan to purchase bags of maize in bulk, hoping to save enough to help her husband put up a building of their own and sponsor the rest of their children’s education through to the university level.

loans.use: To procure maize.

loans.name: Amadu

texts.en:
Amamatu I., 52, has six children – three girls and three boys – one of whom is married while the rest are in senior high and basic school. She lives with her husband, a farmer cultivating palm nuts, plantain and maize, and some of her children in a rented apartment in Koforidua, a small business and farming community near Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana.

For over 20 years, Amamatu has traded in maize, purchasing it from farmers in her community and surrounding towns and trekking to markets to sell it. She is requesting a loan to procure maize in bulk, hoping to save enough to help her husband put up a building of their own and sponsor the rest of their children’s education through to the university level.

loans.use: To procure bags of maize.

loans.name: Debora

texts.en:
Debora K., 55, has six children, - three girls and three boys - the youngest of whom is in junior high school, while the rest are working, some as traders in the city and others as farmers. Living with the family in a rented apartment in Koforidua, a small farming and commercial town not far from Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana, Debora works very hard to support her husband in taking care of the family. She trades in bananas and oranges, a livelihood pursued by many women in the community.

Debra has been in business for 10 years, buying bags of oranges and bananas from farmers in the nearby villages, selling them to retailers in the local market after they have ripened. It has long been her dream to save enough money to support her children in school, so she is requesting a loan to procure bananas and oranges in bulk to increase her profit margin. She hopes to thereby help her youngest to further his education.

loans.use: To procure bananas and oranges.

loans.name: Bituu

texts.en:
Bituu has sold food and clothes in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 4 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $155. She works at her business for 14 hours every day. 

Bituu is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food and clothes to sell. She hopes that this loan will help her increase her profit so that she will be able to grow her business and save money.  

Bituu is 50 years old, married, and has one child aged 34.

loans.use: To buy more food and clothing for her business.

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena Y. is a 47-year-old widow and the mother of eight children, five girls and three boys. Four are currently in school and the rest are working. Living with some of her children in a rented apartment in Koforidua, a small town close to Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana, Abena works very hard to provide for them as a trader in bananas and cassavas.

While sometimes procuring foodstuffs such as plantain and maize, she mainly buys cassava and unripe bananas from farmers in her town and the nearby villages, selling to local retailers. She has been in business for 10 years, and her fondest desire is to save enough money to support the rest of her children in their academics. Abena is therefore requesting a loan to procure bananas and cassavas in bulk so as to maximize her profit margin.

loans.use: To procure bananas and cassavas.

loans.name: Mahbuba

texts.ru: Нишонова Махбуба проживает в городе Турсун-Заде. Возраст 31 год. Замужем и имеет двоих детей. Торгует поэлитиленом. Продает клиенку для сельских жителей , которые используют ее для установки Парниковых сооружений. Сейчас она планирует увеличить товарооборот , путем получения кредита.Это даст возможность увеличить ассортимент товара. Это приведет  к развитию бизнеса. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Mahbuba N., 31, lives in Tursun-Zade, married, and has 2 children. Mahbuba sells plastic film, which is used by the villagers to cover greenhouses. This loan Mahbuba will use to increase the assortment of her products to expand her business. She plans to repay this loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase the assortment of goods sold

loans.name: Ala

texts.en:
Ala A., 60, has six children, - two girls and four boys - and her youngest is still in school, attending junior high. She lives with the family in a rented apartment in Koforidua, a small farming and commercial town not very far from Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana, working very hard to help her husband take care of the family.

Ala sells groceries such as milo, candies, sugar, and many other sweets, buying her goods from wholesalers in the nearby cities and then selling them on a small tabletop by the roadside. Ala has been in business for two years, and it is her dream to save enough money to support her last child in school. She is therefore requesting a loan to procure groceries in bulk to increase her profit margin.

loans.use: To procure groceries.

loans.name: Aguru

texts.en:
Aguru A., 45, is the mother of five children, one boy and four girls. Three are in junior high and primary school and two are learning trades. She lives with them and her husband, a farmer, in Koforidua, a small business and farming town near Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana.

Working hard to support her husband in providing for the family, Aguru has been both a fish monger and banana seller for 15 years. Procuring her fish from large-scale fish mongers in the coastal areas of the country and the bananas from the surrounding towns, she sells in both the local market square and nearby village markets. Aguru is now requesting a loan to buy fish and bananas in bulk to make greater profit so she can help her children in school.

loans.use: To procure bananas and smoked fish.

loans.name: Zarbibi

texts.ru: Махмудова Зарбиби проживает в городе Турсун-Заде. Возраст 52 года. Замужем и имеет шестерых детей. Муж работает на стройке , подсобным рабочим.Сама она занимается бизнесом. торгует клиенкой . Опыт работы в данной сфере уже 4 года. Для того, чтобы обеспечить такую большую семью им с мужем приходиться много работать. Таким образом она развивает свой бизнес. И теперь она хочет получить кредит , который она использует на приобретение стройматериалов и оплату аренды. Стройматериалы использует для пристройки навеса. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Zarbibi M., 52, is married and has 6 children. Zarbibi lives in Tursun-Zade. Her husband works as a helper at a construction site. Zarbibi has been selling plastic covers for 4 years. She applied for this loan to purchase building materials and to pay rent for her stall. Zarbibi will use the building materials to build a shed for her stall. She will repay this loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase building materials and to pay rent for the place of business

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Danaya comprend (04) femmes mariées qui vivent dans des familles monogames et ayant en moyenne 37 ans et 3 enfants. Elles habitent dans le village de  Ségou coura Bamanan (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles font généralement comme activité le petit commerce et ont connu Soro Yiriwaso à travers un  autre groupe de femmes d’une l’association qui partenaire de l’institution. Après avoir correctement remboursé les deux premiers prêt, elles sont à leur 3ème prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter 1600 yards de fibres plastiques, 1 rouleau de corde, 5 morceaux de lièges , 40 morceaux d’argile cuite , 2 sacs de riz et 10 pièces de wax. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Ségou et quelque fois en riz dans les magasins de Ségou coura. Les 1600 yards de fibres plastiques sont tissés en filet sur lesquels on fixe les senis et les fon fons ; Ainsi elles disposent de leur propre filet pour pouvoir pêcher avec leur mari ou leurs enfants sur le fleuve Niger. Les poissons  sont vendus en tas au marché de Médine Ségou et à travers le village de Ségou coura. Le riz et les pagnes wax (tissus très prisés en Afrique de l’ouest) sont revendus en détail à domicile et au marché de Ségou coura au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Leur bénéfice moyen mensuel escompté est de 30 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et à l’achat des fournitures scolaires des enfants. Leur objectif est l’achat de pirogue et d’animaux pour faire l’élevage de petits ruminants.
texts.en:
The Danaya group is made up of four married women who live in monogamous families. They have an average age of 37 and on average, 3 children. They live in the village of Ségou Coura Bamanan (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

They are mostly petty traders and found out about Soro Yiriwaso from another group of women from an association that partners with the micro-finance institution. After having correctly reimbursed their first two loans, they are on their third solidarity loan which will be used to buy 1600 yards of plastic fiber, 1 roll of string, 5 pieces of cork, 40 pieces of fired clay, 2 sacks of rice, and 10 lengths of "wax" (African print cloth). They do their buying at the big open-air market of Ségou and sometimes buy rice in the stores of Ségou Coura. The 1600 yards of plastic fiber will be woven into nets on which "senis" and "fon fons" (floats?) are affixed. Thus they will have their own nets so that they are able to go fishing in the Niger River with their husbands or their children.

The fish are sold by the pile at the market of Médine Ségou and around the village of Ségou Coura. The rice and the African print cloth known as "wax" (cloth that is much esteemed in West Africa) are sold retail from their homes or at the market of Ségou Coura for cash or on credit to a clientele composed of men and women. Their discounted average monthly profit is 30,000 F CFA which will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and to buy school supplies for their children. Their goal is to be able to buy a pirogue (boat for fishing) and animals so that they can raise sheep and goats.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of fishing nets, "wax" African print cloth, and rice

loans.name: Rano

texts.en:
Rano is an enterprising woman. She is always happy to do good work. When she was young, she had a big desire for self-improvement. For about 10 years, she has been running a cattle and sheep-breeding business. This activity allows her to support her two children who are the reason for her being, and she has raised them alone since she separated from her husband several years ago. Both of her children are enrolled in school. Rano lives with them and with her parents, and for this reason, she wants to increase her investment capital to be able to keep supporting them. With your support she will be able to buy new animals. Let's support this mother’s proposal!

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing calves in order to expand her business

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort A., the 38-year-old mother of a boy in junior high school, lives with him and her husband in a rented apartment in the small town of Koforidua, in the Ashanti Region. Her husband is a farmer cultivating crops such as maize and cassava, while Comfort trades in maize and bananas, buying her goods from farmers in nearby villages and selling in the market square and by the roadside.

Comfort has been in this business for over five years and is now requesting a loan to buy maize and bananas in bulk. She is working hard to support her husband so that they can put up a building of their own and give their son the best education possible.

loans.use: To procure bananas and maize.

loans.name: Mavjuda

texts.ru: Махмудова Мавджуда проживает в  городе Турсун-заде. Возраст 33 года. Замужем и имеет троих детей. Образование среднее. Домохозяйка. Но имеет участок земли, который засеивает пшеницей. Получаемый урожай  частично продает на рынке, а часть оставляет себе.планируемый кредит использует для покупки качественных семян и удобрений. Покупка качественной продукции даст возможность подлучить качественный урожай. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Mavjuda M. lives in Tursun-Zade. She is 33, married, and has 3 children. Mavjuda is a housewife. She also has a parcel of land where she grows wheat. Part of her harvest Mavjuda sells at a local market, while keeping the rest for her family. Mavjuda will use this loan to purchase quality seeds and fertilizer. She will repay this loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth O. is 49 years old and married with 6 children. She sells bicycles and bicycle spare parts. She needs the loan amount of N 60,000 to purchase more bicycles to sell. She says thank you to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more bicycles to sell

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq (05) membres du groupe Benkadi  sont majoritairement mariées dans des familles monogamiques avec en moyenne 37 ans et 5 enfants. Les membres du groupe se sont connus dans l’association traditionnelle des femmes du village de Ségou coura Bamanan (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Elles ont connu Soro Yiriwaso à travers l’assemblée générale tenue dans le vestibule du chef de quartier visant la recherche d’une source financement pour les femmes. C’est ainsi qu’elles intègrent le programme crédit de l’institution avec lequel elles sont maintenant à leur 8ème prêt de groupe après avoir remboursé sans difficulté les sept premiers.
 Ce nouveau prêt  sera utilisé pour acheter 50 pagnes en cotonnade (kolèba), les ingrédients du bogolan (1 sac de n’galama, 1 sac d’écorce de raisin sauvage, une bassine d’argile noire, le savon de lessive en morceau et en poudre), 13 pièces  pagnes wax, les ingrédients de l’encens (le magnon kissèni, la plante exotique : le guéni, et 20 flacons de parfum). 
Pour teindre un pagne on fait des dessins avec le mélange d’argile, de savon en poudre avant de le tremper dans la décoction de n’galama et du raisin sauvage. L’encens est produit à partir du n’gueni  immergé dans l’eau de Cologne pendant un mois au moins avant de le malaxer avec le magnon kissèni et les autres parfums. 
Elles se ravitaillent en matériaux de base au Centre Multifonctionnel des femmes de Ségou coura et au grand marché de la vile de Ségou. Les produits sont vendus en ambulant à travers la ville de  Ségou à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 39 330FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et acheter des fournitures scolaires des enfants. Leur objectif est l’achat d’une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
The five members of the group Benkadi are for the most part married women in monogamous families. They average 37 years of age and five children and know one another through the women’s traditional association of the village of Ségou Coura Bamanan (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They found out about Soro Yiriwaso from the general assembly, held in the hall of the district chief, having the aim of finding financial resources for women. This is how the group members became part of the loan program of the micro-credit institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which they are now on their eighth group loan. The first seven loans have been repaid without difficulty.

This new loan will be used to buy: 50 pagnes (lengths of colorful West African cloth) made of cotton (kolèba); the supplies for making bogolan the mud cloth of Mali: 1 sack of n’galama, 1 sack of wild grape skins, a tub of black clay, laundry soap both powdered and in cakes; 13 lengths of WAX brand pagnes; and the ingredients for incense: magnon kissèni, an exotic plant, n’guéni seeds, and 20 bottles of perfume.

To dye pagne cloth, designs are drawn with a mixture of clay and powdered soap that is then wetted in a concoction of n’galama and wild grapes. To make incense, the n’guéni seeds are soaked in eau de cologne for at least a month and then blended with the magnon kissèni and other perfumes.

The women get their basic supplies and equipment at the Centre Multifonctionnel for the women of Ségou Coura and at the grand market of Ségou City. The goods are sold door-to-door throughout Ségou to customers composed of men and women.

The women hope to realize an average monthly profit of 39,330 francs CFA that will be used to repay the loan interest and to buy school supplies for the children. Their objective is to buy a house in which to live.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pagne cloth and ingredients for making incense and mud cloth

loans.name: Mairam

texts.ru: Меликова Майрам живет со своей семьей в одном из дальних кишлаков города Турсун-заде. Замужем и имеет четверых детей. Домохозяйка. Занимается уходом за своим хозяйством, где имеет пару голов КРС. Для того, чтобы увеличить поголовье скота , планирует получить кредит и купить молодого бычка. Погасить кредит сможет течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Mairam M. lives with her family in one of the remote villages around Tursun-Zade. She is married and has 4 children. Mairam is a housewife. In addition, she tends to a small cattle farm. Mairam applied for this loan to purchase a young bull. She plans to repay the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Barchinoy

texts.en:
Barchinoy is a widow who, since she took sole responsibility for raising her young children, has labored tirelessly to provide for all their needs. It was because of her strong work ethic that she found stable employment 10 years ago in cattle and sheep breeding. Things have slowly improved, but she would like to make further progress. She is requesting a loan of $800 USD, to be repaid over 12 months, to improve the installations used to raise animals and provide an environment where she can increase their numbers and improve their living conditions. Let's help make Barchinoy's hard work pay off so that her family can enjoy a better quality of life.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing small cattle in order to expand the business and to improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.name: Akua

texts.en:
Akua K., 55, is the widowed mother of five children - four boys and a girl. Her daughter has completed junior high school and is currently learning a trade, hairdressing, while the boys are still in school. She lives with the children in a rented apartment in Koforidua, a small town close to Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana.

Akua works very hard to provide for her children as a seller of bananas, purchasing the unripe commodity from farmers in nearby villages and then selling them after ripening to retailers in the local market square. In business for three years, she dreams about saving enough money to support her sons in school, so she is requesting a loan to procure bananas in bulk in order to maximize her profit margin.

loans.use: To procure bananas.

loans.name: Mirzo

texts.en:
G. Mirzo is 46 years old. He is married and has four children. Mirzo has been providing transportation services for the last 2 years. Each day on his lorry he transports water to his neighboring villages of Shavkat, Andarsoy, and Somgar. Mirzo dreams that his children will be educated, and for that he is working hard. As a result the business generates a significant income allowing him to support his family. His daily profit is about 120-130 Somoni ($30-35 USD). Currently Mirzo needs to purchase spare parts for his lorry. For this purpose he requests $800 US Dollars for the term of 12 months. This will be his first loan with IMON International, and his evaluation shows he is qualified to receive the loan.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

loans.use: Purchasing spare parts for the lorry.

loans.name: Ismoil

texts.en:
I. Ismoil has been dedicated to cattle farming for the past 8 years, and has vast experience in the field as it is the only business he is in. He is married and the father of three children, who are his responsibility. In order to advance, he has looked for a way to improve his financial situation, and has done so thanks to loans granted by IMON International. These loans were invested by him in the purchase of cows to be fattened and bred and then butchered to sell the meat, or kept to sell the milk. For as long as he has worked with IMON International, he has been an excellent client, who makes his loan repayments on time.

loans.use: Purchasing cattle in order to expand the business

loans.name: Nyètaa Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Nyètaa est composé de huit (08)  femmes,  toutes mariées  qui ont un âge moyen de 32 ans et 5 enfants. Elles vivent majoritairement dans des familles monogamiques dans le village de Zogofina Were II (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali). Les membres du groupe se sont connus à travers des liens de mariage et de voisinage dans le village.
Elles ont connu Soro Yiriwaso à travers les femmes de Zogofina Wêrê I qui mènent les mêmes activités génératrices de revenu qu’elles et qui sont dans le système depuis plusieurs années à l’issu de l’assemblée générale tenue au chef lieu de la commune rurale de Sakoïba. Elles  sont avec l’institution depuis deux ans et sont à leur 3ème prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).
Ce prêt sera  utilisé pour acheter, 1 869 litres de lait frais et 5sacs de mil. Elles s’approvisionnent en lait frais sur place au village et à Kamakono village situé à 3 km ; en mil à travers leurs propres activités journalières au cours des récoltes dans les champs des hommes et à la foire hebdomadaire au grand marché de Ségou. Le lait est vendu frais ou caillé en ambulant dans les quartiers de Ségou et quant au mil, il est d’abord transformé en couscous séché pour être revendu au village à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles  espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 31 150FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et contribuer pour la prise en charge des dépenses de la famille. Leur objectif principal est d’épargner afin d’élever des vaches dans le futur.
texts.en:
The Nyètaa group is composed of eight married women, who, on average, are 32 years old and have 5 children. The majority live in monogamous families in the village of Zogofina Were II (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The members of the group became acquainted through bonds of marriage and neighborhood in the village. They heard about Soro Yiriwaso during general assemblies held at the rural town of Sakoïba, from women in Zogofina Wêrê I who run similar money-making businesses, and who have been part of the system for several years. The group has been with this institution for two years and is seeking its third solidarity group (group loan). This loan will be used to buy 1'869 liters of fresh milk and 5 sacks of millet. They purchase fresh milk in their village, as well as in Kamakono, a village located 3 kilometers away. Millets is obtained from their daily work during harvest season in the men's fields, as well as at the weekly fair at the grand market in Ségou. Milk is sold fresh or sour, itinerantly in the neighborhoods of Ségou. As for the millet, it is firstly transformed in dried couscous, and then sold in the village, to a clientele composed of men and women. They hope to turn an average monthly profit of XOF 31'150 (ca US$ 62), to be used to repay the loan and to contribute to the family expenses. Their main goal is to save money in order to be able to raise cows in the future.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy milk and millet

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena M., 49, is the divorced mother of five children, two girls and three boys, two of whom are in school, one in senior high school and the other in the basic level. The rest have completed school and are working. Abena lives with some of her children in a rented apartment in Koforidua, a small town close to Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana.

Abena works very hard to provide for her children as a trader in bananas and cassavas. In business for ten years, she buys them from farmers in the area and sells them to local retailers. It is Abena’s desire to save enough money to support the rest of her children in their academics, so she is requesting a loan to procure bananas and cassavas in bulk to maximize her profit margin.

loans.use: To procure bananas and cassavas.

loans.name: Abdumalik

texts.en:
K. Abdumalik is a 41-year-old farmer, who lives with his family, consisting of three children and his wife. He lives in the northern part of Tajikistan, in the Spitamen district of Sugd region. Abdumalik has two milk cows and sells dairy products to the local and capital traders. Sahib has 10 years of experience in raising cattle and selling dairy products. The milk products are in very high demand in his village. Hiss orders for these products are very high but the milk his cows give is not enough for traders and he decided to apply for $800 USD to purchase an additional cow and fodder. Abdumalik is very grateful to everyone who is helping him to improve his living with this loan.

loans.use: Purchasing cattle in order to expand the business

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy A. sells drinks in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. Her husband is a commercial driver. Mercy is 36 years old and married with 6 children. She needs a loan to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell.

loans.name: Khonbobo

texts.en:
K. Khonbobo is 34 years old. He is married and has 3 children. Khonbobo is very diligent and hard-working man. Using his car, he has been providing taxi services for five years. In addition, he also sells farm animals. He buys young calves, feeds them for 2-3 month and then sells them at the markets. This business is a decent source of income for Khonbobo and his family. Moreover, Khonbobo sells cows to butchers who provide the city's markets with valuable fresh meat at affordable prices. The client plans to use the loan in order to purchase more young cattle and fodder for them. He plans to repay the loan within 12 months. With your support, Khonbobo will continue to progress.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing cattle in order to expand the business

loans.name: Magdalene

texts.en: Magdalene A. sells gift items and drinks. She travels to Lagos and Onitsha to purchase her goods to sell in Benin City. She is 43 years old and married with 3 children. Her husband sells building materials. She needs the loan to purchase more gift items and drinks to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more gift items and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa S., 40, is the mother of six children, two girls and four boys. Five of her children are currently in junior high and primary school, and one is learning a trade. She lives with the children and her husband, a farmer, in a rented apartment in Koforidua, a small farming and commercial town near Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana.

Industrious as she is, Adwoa has been trading in bananas for over 20 years to help her husband take care of the family. Purchasing the bananas from farmers in the surrounding villages, she sells them at affordable prices to retailers and at the local market under a shed. She is requesting a loan to buy bananas in larger quantities to expand her customer base and make more profit.

loans.use: To procure bananas in bulk.

loans.name: Jurabek

texts.ru: Наботов Джурабек житель района Рудаки. Возраст 43 года, женат и имеет четверых детей. Работает таксистом. Кроме того имеет маленький магазинчик , где торгует продуктами питания. Кредит планирует получить для того, чтобы увеличить товарооборот. Товра привозит из города Душанбе, покупая у оптовых реализаторов. Погасиьть кредит сможет в течение 12 месцев.
texts.en:
Jurabek N. lives in Rudaky region. He is 43, married and has 4 children. Jurabek drives a taxi. In addition, he owns a small food store. Jurabek N. applied for this loan to increase the volume of goods sold. He will repay the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase the sales volume

loans.name: Lewis

texts.en: Lewis U. sells provisions, drinks and foodstuffs. He has been in this business for a long time, and hopes to expand the business. Lewis is 54 years old and married with 2 children. He needs the loan to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Lébougui Group

texts.fr: A  l’écovillage de Mekhé (http://www.sem-fund.org/mekhe.php), les activités avicoles  sont rentables et sont valorisées pour contribuer à l’amélioration du régime alimentaire des ménages en protéines animales. C’est pourquoi, Les femmes du groupement disposant déjà d’un poulailler, voudraient dès réception du prêt, acheter  des poussins et  aliments de volaille. Chaque opération relative à l’élevage dure 45 jours  et 20 jours serviront à l’écoulement du produit. Cette opération sera reconduite autant de fois que nécessaire pendant un an.
texts.en:
In the ecovillage of Mekhé (http://www.sem-fund.org/mekhe.php), poultry businesses have proved to be remunerative and useful since they contribute to the improvement of village households' diets by supplying complete protein. This is why the women of this group, who already have a chicken yard, want to use the loan, as soon as they receive it, to buy chicks and chickenfeed. It takes 45 days to raise the chicks and 20 days to have them all sold. This operation will be repeated as often as necessary over one year.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: poultry raising

loans.name: Sabougnouman Group

texts.fr:
Les neufs (09) membres du groupe Sabougnouman  ont une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans et sont toutes mariées dans des familles monogamiques avec 6 enfants. Elles habitent le village de Zogofina Were II (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles font essentiellement l’élevage et la vente du lait et ses dérivés.
Après avoir correctement remboursé les deux premiers prêts, ce groupe est à son troisième prêt solidaire.
Ce prêt  servira à acheter, 85 sacs de tourteau et 2 sacs de riz. Elles s’approvisionnent en tourteau et en riz à la foire hebdomadaire au grand marché de Ségou (à la place des forains de Niono). Ce tourteau sert à alimenter leurs vaches laitières pendant la saison sèche en plus, des fanes d’arachides et de niébé, des fourrages et des sons de mil. Le tourteau permet d’augmenter la quantité de lait produite. Le lait est vendu frais ou caillé en ambulant dans les quartiers de Ségou ; le riz est vendu dans le village et au marché de Médine de la ville de Ségou en détail, au comptant et à crédit à divers clients. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 33 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt,  acheter du tourteau et pour faire face aux petits besoins des enfants (habillement et frais médicaux). 
Leur objectif principal est l’augmentation des fonds de commerce dont les ressources générées serviront à l’achat de vaches laitières.
texts.en:
The nine members of the group Sabougnouman are all married women who average 38 years of age and live in monogamous families with six children each in the village of Zogofina Were II (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They essentially raise livestock and sell milk and milk products.

After having correctly repaid their first two loans, this group is on its third group loan, which will be use to buy 85 sacks of milled seeds and two sacks of rice. Supplies are gotten at the weekly fair at the grand marketplace of Ségou (at the vendors’ square of Niono). The milled seeds are used to feed their milk cows during the dry season; also used are the winnowing remains from processing peanuts and black-eyed peas, fodder, and millet bran. The milled seeds enable the increased production of milk, which is sold, fresh or curdled, and door-to-door in the Ségou area. The rice is sold in the village and at the Médine marketplace of Ségou. These sales are made at the retail level, cash or credit accepted, to a diverse customer base.

The group members plan on realizing an average monthly profit of 33,000 francs CFA that will be used for repaying the loan interest, buying some milled seeds, and addressing the needs of the children (clothing and medical costs). Their main objective is to increase their working capital, which generates income that will be used to buy milk cows.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy milled seeds and some rice

loans.name: Alex

texts.en: Alex is 40-years-old and is married with four children. He lives in Benin City where he uses a motorcycle to convey passengers from one location to another. He is requesting a loan amount of $350 (N50,000) to purchase one additional motorcycle to enable him to meet the demands of his customers. He says thanks to Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for transportation

loans.name: Omolara

texts.en: Omolara is 34-years-old, married, and lives in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria. She sells electrical products and is requesting a loan amount of $475 (N70, 000) to purchase more product inventory to sell. She hopes to increase profits in her business. She says thanks to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more electrical products to sell

loans.name: Muna

texts.en:
Muna H. is thirty years old. She is married and has six children: two sons and four daughters. Five of her children are currently in school, both junior high and primary school. Her youngest child is still too young to attend school. Muna’s husband is a farmer who cultivates cassava and palm nuts. The family lives in a house in a small town called Koforidua, located near Offinso in the Ashanti Region. It is a farming as well as a commercial community.
Industrious as she is, Muna is engaged in a banana sales business to help her husband financially support the family. She buys bags of banana from farmers in the surrounding villages and then sells them to retailers in the local market. Muna has been in the business for over ten years. Currently, she needs a loan to buy more banana in large quantities to be able to increase her sales and profit. She hopes to thereby improve her family's living conditions and help pay for her children's further education.

loans.use: Purchase of banana for re-sale

loans.name: Firuza

texts.ru: Сулаймонова Фируза проживает в районе Рудаки.. Возраст 34 года , замужем и имеет четверых детей. Занимается торговлей. Торгует одеждой. Торговой точки нет, она торгует по кишлакам. То есть она ходит из дома в дом , предлагая товар. Кредит планирует получить для того чтобы увеличить товарооборот. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 12 месяцев.Бизнес приносит доход , но если она увеличит товарооборот , то она сможет увеличить доходность дела.
texts.en:
Firuza S. lives in Rudaki region. She is 34, married, and has 4 children. Firuza sells clothing. She has no permanent location for her business, so she travels with her merchandise from one village to another. Firuza S. applied for this loan to finance purchase of seasonal clothing inventory. She plans to repay the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase seasonal clothing inventory

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en: Yaa N. is 30 years old. She is married and has two children - a son and a daughter. The son is studying at an elementary school, while the daughter is yet to start. Yaa's family lives in a rented apartment in Koforidua, a suburb of the city of Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. Koforidua is a farming as well as a commercial community, and the majority of its inhabitants are farmers or traders. Yaa works hard to help her husband financially support the family. Her husband is a mechanic who owns a workshop and earns money repairing damaged vehicles. Yaa buys tubers of yam from Techiman in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana and sometimes from the surrounding villages and then sells fresh yam in the local market square as well as distributes it to food vendors in her community. She has been in this business for about five years. Currently, Yaa needs a loan to buy tubers of yam in bulk in order to cut down on cost that she otherwise incurs as a result of the frequent trips to procure the yam tubers. She hopes to thereby increase her business profit margin and be able to better support her husband in paying for their children's education.

loans.use: Purchase of tubers of yam for sale

loans.name: Osahenrunmwen

texts.en: Osahenrunmwen is 33-years-old and is married with two children. She lives in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria where she has a hair salon and creates lovely hair styles for her customers. Osahenrunmwen also sells hair-related products such as hair extensions, hair cream, etc. She has been in this business for a long time. She is requesting a loan amount of $275 (N40, 000) to purchase more salon products to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more hair-related products to sell in the salon

loans.name: Ramatu

texts.en: Ramatu Abubakari is 28 years old. She is married and has two children - a son and a daughter. Ramatu's daughter is already in school, while her son is yet to start. Ramatu and her family live in a rented apartment in Koforidua, a suburb of Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. Koforidua is a farming as well as a commercial community, and many of its inhabitants are either farmers or traders. Ramatu works hard to help her husband financially support the family. Her husband works for one of the timber firms in the locality. Ramatu herself earns income as a food vendor. She prepares and sells porridge at the market square in the mornings. Porridge is eaten for breakfast by many Ghanaians. Ramatu procures the necessary ingredients, such as maize and millet, from Techiman in the Brong Ahafo Region where they are readily available. She has been in the food sales business for about three years and currently needs a loan to buy millet and maize in bulk in order to cut down on the cost that she otherwise incurs as a result of the frequent trips made to procure the porridge ingredients. She hopes to thereby increase her business profit and be able to better support her husband in paying for their children's education.

loans.use: Purchase of maize and millet

loans.name: Boubacar

texts.fr:
Monsieur Boubacar B. est âgé de 28 ans et vit dans une famille monogame avec son enfant et sa femme dans le quartier Torakabougou dans la préfecture de Bougouni(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Il abandonna très tôt l’école pour se consacrer à la photographie qu’il a appris auprès d’un ami. Avec une expérience de 7 ans, Monsieur Boubacar B. maîtrise bien son activité et très sollicité au niveau de la ville de Bougouni avec une clientèle généralement composée de jeunes. C’est surtout pendant les vacances, les jours de mariages(Jeudi et Dimanche), les soirées dansantes et les baptèmes que son activité est très élévé.
Dans sa recherche de ressources financières complementaire, il décida d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinanace Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel.
Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, un appareil photo, et des péliculles.
Il s’approvisionne en appareil photo et en péliculles à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali).
Monsiuer Boubacar B. compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40 000 FCFA qu’il envisage utiliser pour payer les intérêts du prêt et faire la finition de sa maison.
texts.en:
Mr. Boubacar B. is 28 years old and lives in a monogamous family with his child and wife in the Torakabougou district of Bougouni prefecture (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). He left school very early in order to devote himself to photography, which he learned from a friend. With seven years of experience, he is mastering his work and is in high demand by customers general composed of young people in the city of Bougouni. He is particularly busy during vacation time, on wedding days (Thursdays and Sundays), for dance parties, and at baptisms.

In his search for supplemental financial resources, he decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which he is on his first individual loan. This loan will be used to buy a camera and film. He gets his supplies in Bamako, the capital of Mali.

He plans on realizing a monthly profit of 40,000 francs CFA that he envisions using to pay the loan interest and to complete his house.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a camera and film

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice T. is 46 years old. She is married and has six children - three sons and three daughters. Her two youngest children are still in school: one is in the senior high, and the other - in the junior high school. The other ones have completed junior high school, but have not been able to continue. They are currently learning trades - hair dressing, dressmaking, etc. Alice's family lives in a rented apartment in a small town called Koforidua in the Ashanti Region. Her husband is a teacher at a local government-run school, while Alice herself works as a maize and banana trader. She buys the produce from farmers in the nearby villages and sells it to retailers in her community. She also prepares a dish made of ripe banana and roasted groundnut and sells it by the roadside. Alice has been in this business for seven years, and now needs a loan to buy maize and banana in bulk. She hopes to thereby increase her business profit and be able to better support her husband in paying for the construction of a house for their family and for the further schooling of their youngest two children.

loans.use: Purchase of banana and maize

loans.name: Moussa Kamissoko

texts.fr:
Monsieur M. K. a 31 ans et vit avec son enfant et sa femme  dans la  quartier Hérémakono Nord de la préfecture de Bougouni (troisième région administraive de la république du Mali).
Monsieur M. K., aprés avoir abandonné l’école au niveau des études secondaire(collège), est resté pendant des années sans emploi. C’est ainsi qu’il commença les activités économiques notamment la vente d’une boutique d’articles divers. Avec une expérience de 2 ans, il maîtrise bien cette activité qu’il embrassa d’ailleurs à travers les conseils d’un de ses amis. Aujourd’hui il jouit d’une notoriété sans égal dans la ville de Bougouni.
 Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire le besoin de sa clientèle, il décide d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel.
Il veut utiliser ce prêt pour acheter des articles divers pour sa boutique. Il s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) auprès des grossistes. Il effectue ses ventes dans sa boutique à une clientèlle est composée de la population locale.
Avec ce prêt, Monsieur M. K. compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 32 000 FCFA. Avec ce bénéfice il envisage agrandir sa boutique, payer les intérêts du prêt et à assurer les dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
Mr. M. K., age 31, lives with his child and wife in the Hérémakono Nord district of Bougouni prefecture (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After dropping out of middle school, he remained unemployed for years. This is why he got started in commerce, notably in selling various goods from a shop. With two years of experience, he is mastering this work, which by the way he embraced through the advice of one of his friends. Today, he enjoys unmatched distinction in Bougouni City.

Concerned about satisfying the needs of his customers better, he decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which he is on his first individual loan. He wants to use this loan to buy various goods for his shop. Supplies are gotten in Bamako (capital of Mali) from wholesalers. His sales are made out of his shop to customers composed of local people.

With this loan, he plans on realizing a monthly profit of 32,000 francs CFA that he envisions using for expanding his shop, for paying the loan interest, and for ensuring that family expenses are covered.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various merchandise for his shop

loans.name: Susana

texts.en: Susana N. is 50 years old. She is married and has nine children - five daughters and four sons. Her three youngest children are still in school - junior high and elementary. The other ones have already completed their education and are now working. Some are engaged in the trading business in the city, while the others earn income as farmers. Susana's family lives in a rented apartment in Koforidua, a small commercial and farming community located near Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. Susana works very hard to help her husband financially support their family. She earns income trading banana and oranges, which is a business run by many women in the community. Susana buys bags of oranges and unripe banana from farmers in the nearby villages, stores the banana to ripe and then sells it to retailers in the local market. She has been in this business for ten years and has always dreamed of saving enough money to support her children in school. She is therefore asking for a loan to buy banana and oranges in bulk to be able to increase her business profit margin.

loans.use: Purchase of banana and oranges

loans.name: Sairambi

texts.ru:
Мирзоева Сайрамби жительница района Рудаки. Возраст 50 лет, замужем и имеет пятеро детей. меет высшее образование. По профессии врач. Но нигде не работает. Занимается торговлей. Торгует бензином.
Товар привозит из города Душанбе, заполняет бочки и продает ведрами. Кредит планирует получить для того, чтобы закупить бензин , так как цены на горючее упали. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Sairambi M. is a resident of the Rudaki region. She is 50 years old, is married and has five children. She has a university education and is a doctor by profession, but does not work anywhere. Sairambi works in sales and sells gasoline. She transports her product from Dushanbe, fills up kegs and sells it by the pail. She would like to take out a loan to purchase gasoline, because oil prices have fallen. Sairambi can pay back the loan over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase gasoline

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr:
Mamadou D. intervient dans la vente et la réparation des pneus à Grand Dakar.
Il sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer son activité qui est rentable. Grâce aux services qu'il offre, il arrive à nourir sa famille et appuyer les parents restés au village.
texts.en:
Mamadou D. works selling and repairing tires in Grand Dakar.

He is requesting this loan to bolster his business which is remunerative. Thanks to the services he offers, he is able to feed his family and support his relatives back home in the village.


Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: sale and repair of tires

loans.name: Bollo Liguéye Group

texts.fr: Mékhé (http://www.sem-fund.org/mekhe.php), est célèbre de par sa position commerciale stratégique (Chemin de fer) et ses riches potentialités artisanales (Chaussures & Vannerie). C'est une région fortement agricole et l'activité économique se résume au  commerce, à l'élevage, à  l'agriculture, à l'artisanat, etc. Ce qui a poussé les femmes du groupement de Bollo Liguéye a évolué dans le secteur du commerce. Certaines sont des vendeuses « ambulantes », d’autres disposent d’étals sur le marché. Connaissant bien le secteur  de l’évolution des marchés, elles voudraient  continuer à progresser dans ce domaine de commerce avec un projet de microcrédit en achetant de la marchandise et en la revendant (tissu, bijoux, chaussures, produits artisanaux).
texts.en:
Mékhé (http://www.sem-fund.org/mekhe.php), is famous for its strategic commercial location (on the railway line) and its potential wealth in handmade articles (shoes, woven baskets). This is a very agricultural region and economic activities are in buying and selling, livestock-raising, agriculture, handicrafts, etc. This has encouraged the women of the Bollo Liguéye group to go into commercial activities. Some are door-to-door saleswomen, others have displays at the market. Quite familiar with the evolution of this marketing sector, they would like to continue to progress in this domain with a micro-credit project involving buying and re-selling goods (cloth, jewelry, shoes, handicrafts).

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying and selling goods

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en: Theresa sells groceries and provisions. She is requesting a loan amount of $225 (N30, 000) to purchase more food products and provisions to sell.  She hopes to expand this business with more funds. Theresa is 50-years-old and is married with seven children. She lives in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria. She says thanks to all that make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and provisions to sell

loans.name: Alain

texts.fr: Alain M. intervient dans le secteur du transport. Il fait la location et la formation pour le permis de conduire avec son auto-école situé au centre ville de Ziguinchor. Il demande ce crédit pour l'entretien et la réparation de son outil de travail à savoir sa voiture.
texts.en:
Alain M. works in the transport sector. He does rental and teaches driver's education in his driving school situated in the center of the town of Ziguinchor. He is requesting this loan to maintain and repair the tool of his trade, namely his car.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: repairing and maintaining his car used for driver's ed

loans.name: Amaeze

texts.en: Amaeze is 50-years-old and is married with five children. She lives in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria where she sells provisions like noodles, toothpaste, bathing soap, detergent and drinks. She is requesting a loan amount of $475 (N70, 000) to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders and LAPO micro finance for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Faith

texts.en: Faith is 27-years-old and is married with three children. She sells rechargeable phone cards and she also rents music videos. Faith is requesting a loan amount of $ 275 (N40, 000) to purchase more rechargeable phone cards and music videos.  She hopes to expand her business. She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more rechargeable phone cards and music videos.

loans.name: Vivienne

texts.en: Vivienne sells clothes and jewelry. She travels to Lagos and Onitsha to purchase her goods to sell in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria whee she lives. She loves this business and is requesting a loan amount of $475 (N70, 000) to purchase more clothes and jewelery to sell. She is 27-years-old and single. Vivienne is grateful to Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and jewelry to sell

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en: Mabel O. is a seamstress and also sells tailoring materials. She is requesting a loan amount of $625 (N90,000) to purchase more tailoring materials to sell. It will help to boost her income to take care of her family, and also improve her delivery times to her customers. She is 52-years-old and is married with six children. Her husband is a civil servant who does not receive a salary from the government. She is from Edo State, Nigeria.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Josefa Maritza

texts.es: Doña Josefa Maritza M. tiene 51 años, está casada, y tiene 4 hijos. La actividad económica a la que se dedica Doña Josefa es la venta de carne de res y cerdo. Hace veinte años que tiene este negocio, y durante los primeros cinco anos, ella tuvo muchos problemas con mantener una base consistente de clientes. Con suerte, la ubicación del negocio está en un puesto de venta en el mercadito de Sutiaba en León, donde se experimenta mucho tráfico. La idea de establecer este negocio ocurrió porque su esposo había quedado desempleado, y entre los dos decidieron apoyarse y procurar enfrentar lo que les estaba aconteciendo. Además, Doña Josefa quiso establecer este negocio porque usualmente los mercadores no ofrecen carne de buena calidad y ella quería ser una de las pocas lo que hiciera. El financiamiento es para capital de trabajo destinado a la compra de más carne y ella desea obtener un mayor margen de ganancias al momento de realizar la venta de su producto. Al final, ella sueña con un hermoso puesto de ventas que le genere los ingresos necesarios para poder construir una vivienda en mejores condiciones.
texts.en:
Josefa Maritza M. is 51 years old, married, and has 4 children. The economic activity that Josefa carries out is the sale of beef and pork. She has had this business for the past 20 years, and during the first 5 years she faced many problems maintaining a consistent client base. With luck, the location of her business is in a stall in the small market of Sutiaba in León, where there is much foot traffic. The idea of establishing this business arose because her husband had become unemployed, and between the two they decided to support one another and try to confront what was happening. Moreover, Josefa wanted to establish this business because usually the merchants didn’t offer good quality meat and she wanted to be one of the few that did. The loan will be used for work capital destined for the purchase of more meat and she wishes to obtain a higher earnings margin when she sells her product. In the end, she wishes to have a beautiful stall that generates the necessary income to be able to build a house in better conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Work capital destined for the purchase of more meat.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jimmy

texts.es:
Jimmy vive en casa alquilada con su mama en la Av. Buenos Aires de la zona de Tacagua de la ciudad de La Paz; la actividad que el realiza es la atención de eventos, como ser  matrimonios, cumpleaños, etc. Cuenta con un equipo de amplificación, pero aún no está completo. El crédito que solicita es para comprar mas equipos (1 parlante y un par de micrófonos) y reparar los que tiene, ya que esta actividad es su única fuente generadora de ingresos y necesita tener su equipo en buenas condiciones.

Esta es la primera vez que acude a Impro para solicitar un crédito y su actividad microempresaria y el análisis financiero lo califican para obtener uno.
texts.en:
Jimmy lives in a rented house with his mother on Buenos Aires Avenue in the Tacagua region of the city of La Paz. He works at events, such as weddings, birthdays, etc. He depends on an amplification system, but it is still not complete. The loan he requests is for buying more equipment (one speaker and a pair of microphones) and to repair those that he has, since this business is his only source of income and he needs to have his equipment in good condition. This is the first time he has come to Impro to request a loan and his small-business ownership and financial analysis qualify him for one.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a speaker, microphones, and repair other equipment for his DJ business.

loans.name: Maria A.

texts.es:
La señora María vive en alquiler con su mama y su hijita en la calle D de la zona las Lomas de la ciudad de La Paz; la actividad que ella realiza es la venta de material reciclable, ella compra botellas desechables, cartón, ropa usada, alambres y otros los cuales los separa y los vende por Kilo. Con esta actividad ella trabaja casi 10 años y es su única fuente generadora de ingresos.

El crédito que solicita es para aumentar su capital, comprar más materiales, seleccionarlos y venderlos  y así poder mantener este negocio.

Es cliente  de Impro desde el año 2006 y su historial de pagos es muy bueno por lo que consideramos que  puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
María rents her home and lives with her mother and her young daughter on "D" street in the "Las Lomas" neighbourhood of La Paz. She sells recyclables: she buys disposable bottles, cardboard, used clothing, wire and other materials which she separates and sells by the kilogram. She has been doing this for 10 years; this is her only source of income.
